Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: [Sidenote: p. 147]

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Thorhall was a wealthy man, and especially in cattle, so that no man had as

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: much live stock as he. He was not a chief, yet a substantial yeoman. The

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: place was much haunted, and he found it hard to get a shepherd to suit him.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: He sought counsel of many wise men, what device he should follow, but he

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: got no counsel which was of use to him. Thorhall rode each summer to the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: All-Thing; he had good horses. That was one summer at the All-Thing, that

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Thorhall went to the booth of Skapti Thoroddsson, the Law-man.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Skapti was the wisest of men, and gave good advice if he was asked. There

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: was this difference between Skapti and his father Thorodd: Thorodd had

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: second sight, and some men called him underhanded; but Skapti gave to every

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: man that advice which he believed would avail, if it were kept to: so he

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: was called 'Better than his father.' Thorhall went to the booth of Skapti.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Skapti greeted Thorhall well, for he knew that he was a prosperous man, and

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: asked what news he had.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Thorhall said, "I should like good counsel from thee." "I am little use at

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: that," said Skapti. "But what is thy need?" {164}

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Thorhall said, "It happens so, that it is difficult for me to keep my

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: shepherds: they easily get hurt, and some will not serve their time. And

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: now no one will take on the task, who knows what is before him."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Skapti answered, "There must be some evil being about, if men are more

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: unwilling to look after thy sheep than those of other folk. Now because

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: thou hast sought counsel of me, I will find thee a shepherd, who is named

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Glam, a Swede, from Sylgsdale, who came out to Iceland last summer. He is

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: great and strong, but not much to everybody's taste."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Thorhall said that he would not mind that, if he guarded the sheep well.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Skapti said that if Glam had not the strength and courage to do that, there

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: was no hope of anyone else. Then Thorhall went out; this was when the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: All-Thing was nearly ending.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Thorhall missed two light bay horses, and he went himself to look for

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: them--so it seems that he was not a great man. He went up under Sledge-hill

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and south along the mountain called Armannsfell.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Then he saw where a man came down from Gothashaw, bearing faggots on a

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: horse. They soon met, and Thorhall asked him his name, and he said he was

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: called Glam. Glam [Sidenote: p. 148] was tall and strange in bearing, with

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: blue[299] and glaring eyes, and wolf-grey hair. Thorhall opened his eyes

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: when he saw him, but yet he discerned that this was he to whom he had been

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: sent.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "What work art thou best fitted for?" said Thorhall.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Glam said he was well fitted to watch sheep in the winter.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "Wilt thou watch my sheep?" said Thorhall. "Skapti gave thee into my hand."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "You will have least trouble with me in your house if I go my own way, for

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: I am hard of temper if I am not pleased," said Glam.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "That will not matter to me," said Thorhall, "and I wish that thou shouldst

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: go to my house."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "That may I well do," said Glam, "but are there any difficulties?"

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "It is thought to be haunted," said Thorhall.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "I am not afraid of such phantoms," said Glam, "and it seems to me all the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: less dull."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "Thou wilt need such a spirit," said Thorhall, "and it is better that the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: man there should not be a coward."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: After that they struck their bargain, and Glam was to come at the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: winter-nights [14th-16th of October]. Then they parted, and Thorhall found

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: his horses where he had just been searching. Thorhall rode home and thanked

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Skapti for his good deed.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Summer passed, and Thorhall heard nothing of his shepherd, and no one knew

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: anything of him; but at the time appointed he came to Thorhall's Farm. The

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: yeoman greeted him well, but all the others could not abide him, and

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Thorhall's wife least of all. Glam undertook the watching of the sheep, and

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: it gave him little trouble. He had a great deep voice, and the sheep came

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: together as soon as he called them. There was a church at Thorhall's Farm,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: but Glam would not go to it. He would have nothing to do with the service,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and was godless; he was obstinate and surly and abhorred by all.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Now time went on till it came to Yule eve. Then Glam rose early and called

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: for meat. The yeoman's wife answered, "That is not the custom of Christian

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: men to eat meat today, because tomorrow is the first day of Yule," said

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: she, "and therefore it is right that we should first fast today."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: He answered, "Ye have many superstitions which I see are good for nothing.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: I do not know that men fare better now [Sidenote: p. 149] than before, when

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: they had nought to do with such things. It seemed to me a better way when

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: men were called heathen; and I want my meat and no tricks."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: The yeoman's wife said, "I know for a certainty that it will fare ill with

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: thee today, if thou dost this evil thing."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Glam bade her bring the meat at once, else he said it should be worse for

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: her. She dared not do otherwise than he willed, and when he had eaten he

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: went out, foul-mouthed.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Now it had gone so with the weather that it was heavy all round, and

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: snow-flakes were falling, and it was blowing loud, and grew much worse as

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: the day went on. The shepherd {166} was heard early in the day, but less

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: later. Then wind began to drive the snow, and towards evening it became a

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: tempest. Then men came to the service, and so it went on to nightfall. Glam

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: did not come home. Then there was talk whether search ought not to be made

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: for him, but because there was a tempest and it was pitch dark, no search

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: was attempted. That Yule night he did not come home, and so men waited till

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: after the service [next, i.e. Christmas, morning]. But when it was full

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: day, men went to search, and found the sheep scattered in the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: snow-drifts[300], battered by the tempest, or strayed up into the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: mountains. Then they came on a great space beaten down, high up in the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: valley. It looked to them as if there had been somewhat violent wrestling

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: there, because the stones had been torn up for a distance around, and the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: earth likewise. They looked closely and saw where Glam lay a little

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: distance away. He was dead, and blue like Hel and swollen like an ox. They

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: had great loathing of him, and their souls shuddered at him. Nevertheless

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: they strove to bring him to the church, but they could get him no further

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: than the edge of a ravine a little below, and they went home leaving

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: matters so, and told the yeoman what had happened. He asked what appeared

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: to have been the death of Glam. They said that, from the trodden spot, up

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: to a place beneath the rocks high in the valley, they had tracked marks as

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: big as if a cask-bottom had been stamped down, and great drops of blood

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: with them. So men concluded from this, that the evil thing which had been

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: there before must have killed Glam, but Glam must have done it damage which

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: had been enough, in that nought has ever happened since from that evil

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: thing.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: The second day of Yule it was again essayed to bring Glam to the church.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Beasts of draught were harnessed, but they could not move him where it was

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: level ground and not down hill, so they departed, leaving matters so.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: The third day the priest went with them, and they searched [Sidenote: p.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: 150] all day, but Glam could not be found. The priest would go no {167}

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: more, but Glam was found when the priest was not in the company. Then they

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: gave up trying to carry him to the church, and buried him where he was,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: under a cairn.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: A little later men became aware that Glam was not lying quiet. Great harm

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: came to men from this, so that many fell into a swoon when they saw him,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and some could not keep their wits. Just after Yule, men thought they saw

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: him at home at the farm. They were exceedingly afraid, and many fled away.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Thereupon Glam took to riding the house-roofs at nights, so that he nearly

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: broke them in. He walked almost night and day. Men hardly dared to go up

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: into the dale, even though they had business enough. Men in that

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: country-side thought great harm of this.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: In the spring Thorhall got farm-hands together and set up house on his

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: land. Then the apparition began to grow less frequent whilst the sun's

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: course was at its height; and so it went on till midsummer. That summer a

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: ship came out to Hunawater. On it was a man called Thorgaut. He was an

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: outlander by race, big and powerful; he had the strength of two men. He was

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: in no man's service, and alone, and he wished to take up some work, since

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: he had no money. Thorhall rode to the ship, and met Thorgaut. He asked him

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: if he would work for him. Thorgaut said that might well be, and that he

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: would make no difficulties.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "But thou must be prepared," said Thorhall, "that it is no place for

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: weaklings, by reason of the hauntings which have been going on for a while,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: for I will not let thee into a trap."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Thorgaut answered, "It does not seem to me that I am undone, even though I

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: were to see some little ghosts. It must be no easy matter for others if I

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: am frightened, and I will not give up my place for that."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: So now they agreed well, and Thorgaut was to watch the sheep when winter

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: came.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Now the summer passed on. Thorgaut took charge of the sheep at the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: winter-nights. He was well-pleasing to all. Glam ever came home and rode on

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: the roofs. Thorgaut thought it sporting, and said that the thrall would

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: have to come nearer {168} in order to scare him. But Thorhall bade him keep

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: quiet: "It is best that ye should not try your strength together." Thorgaut

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: said, "Verily, your courage is shaken out of you: I shall not drop down

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: with fear between day and night over such talk."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Now things went on through the winter up to Yule-tide. On Yule evening the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: shepherd went out to his sheep. Then [Sidenote: p. 151] the yeoman's wife

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: said, "It is to be hoped that now things will not go in the old way."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: He answered, "Be not afraid of that, mistress; something worth telling will

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: have happened if I do not come back."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Then he went to his sheep. The weather was cold, and it snowed much.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Thorgaut was wont to come home when it was twilight, but now he did not

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: come at that time. Men came to the service, as was the custom. It seemed to

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: people that things were going as they had before. The yeoman wished to have

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: search made for the shepherd, but the church-goers excused themselves, and

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: said they would not risk themselves out in the hands of the trolls by

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: night. And the yeoman did not dare to go, so the search came to nothing.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: On Yule-day, when men had eaten, they went and searched for the shepherd.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: They went first to Glam's cairn, because men thought that the shepherd's

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: disappearance must have been through his bringing-about. But when they came

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: near the cairn they saw great things, for there they found the shepherd

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: with his neck broken and not a bone in him whole. Then they carried him to

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: the church, and no harm happened to any man from Thorgaut afterwards; but

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Glam began to increase in strength anew. He did so much that all men fled

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: away from Thorhall's Farm, except only the yeoman and his wife.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Now the same cattle-herd had been there a long time. Thorhall would not let

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: him go, because of his good-will and good service. He was far gone in age

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and was very unwilling to leave: he saw that everything went to waste which

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: the yeoman had, if no one looked after it. And once after mid-winter it

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: happened one morning that the yeoman's wife went to the byre to milk the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: cows as usual. It was quite light, because no one dared to go out before,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: except the cattle-herd: he went {169} out as soon as it dawned. She heard

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: great cracking in the byre and a hideous bellowing. She ran back, crying

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: out, and said she did not know what devilry was going on in the byre.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: The yeoman went out, and came to the cattle, and they were goring each

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: other. It seemed to him no good to stay there, and he went further into the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: hay-barn. He saw where the cattle-herd lay, and he had his head in one

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: stall and his feet in the next. He lay on his back. The yeoman went to him

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and felt him. He soon found that he was dead, and his back-bone broken in

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: two; it had been broken over the partition slab.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Now it seemed no longer bearable to Thorhall, and he left his farm with all

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: that he could carry away; but all the live-stock [Sidenote: p. 152] left

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: behind Glam killed. After that he went through all the dale and laid waste

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: all the farms up from Tongue. Thorhall spent what was left of the winter

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: with his friends. No man could go up into the dale with horse or hound,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: because it was slain forthwith. But when spring came, and the course of the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: sun was highest, the apparitions abated somewhat. Now Thorhall wished to go

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: back to his land. It was not easy for him to get servants, but still he set

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: up house at Thorhall's Farm.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: All went the same way as before. When autumn came on the hauntings began to

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: increase. The yeoman's daughter was most attacked, and it fared so that she

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: died. Many counsels were taken, but nothing was done. Things seemed to men

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: to be looking as if all Water-dale must be laid waste, unless some remedies

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: could be found.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Now the story must be taken up about Grettir, how he sat at home at Bjarg

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: that autumn, after he had parted from Barthi-of-the-Slayings at Thorey's

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Peak. And when it had almost come to the winter-nights, Grettir rode from

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: home, north over the neck to Willow-dale, and was a guest at Authun's Farm.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: He was fully reconciled to Authun, and gave him a good axe, and they spake

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: of their wish for friendship one with the other. (Authun dwelt long at

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Authun's Farm, and much goodly offspring had he. Egil was his son, who

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: wedded Ulfheith, daughter of Eyjolf Guthmundson; and their son was Eyjolf,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: who was slain at the All-Thing. He was father of Orm, chaplain to {170}

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Bishop Thorlak.) Grettir rode north to Water-dale and came on a visit to

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Tongue. At that time Jokul Barthson lived there, Grettir's uncle. Jokul was

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: a man great and strong and very proud. He was a seafaring man, and very

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: over-bearing, yet of great account. He received Grettir well, and Grettir

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: was there three nights.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: There was so much said about the apparitions of Glam that nothing was

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: spoken of by men equally with that. Grettir inquired exactly about the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: events which had happened. Jokul said that nothing more had been spoken

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: than had verily occurred. "But art thou anxious, kinsman, to go there?"

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Grettir said that that was the truth. Jokul begged him not to do so, "For

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: that is a great risk of thy luck, and thy kinsmen have much at stake where

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: thou art," said he, "for none of the young men seems to us to be equal to

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: thee; but ill will come of ill where Glam is, and it is much better to have

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: to do with mortal men than with evil creatures like that."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Grettir said he was minded to go to Thorhall's Farm and [Sidenote: p. 153]

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: see how things had fared there. Jokul said, "I see now that it is of no

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: avail to stop thee, but true it is what men say, that good-luck is one

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: thing, and goodliness another."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "Woe is before one man's door when it is come into another's house. Think

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: how it may fare with thee thyself before the end," said Grettir.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Jokul answered, "It may be that both of us can see somewhat into the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: future, but neither can do aught in the matter."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: After that they parted, and neither was pleased with the other's

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: foreboding.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Grettir rode to Thorhall's Farm, and the yeoman greeted him well. He asked

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: whither Grettir meant to go, but Grettir said he would stay there over the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: night if the yeoman would have it so. Thorhall said he owed him thanks for

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: being there, "But few men find it a profit to stay here for any time. Thou

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: must have heard what the dealings are here, and I would fain that thou

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: shouldst have no troubles on my account; but though thou shouldst come

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: whole away, I know for certain that thou {171} wilt lose thy steed, for no

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: one who comes here keeps his horse whole."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Grettir said there were plenty of horses, whatever should become of this

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: one.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Thorhall was glad that Grettir would stay there, and welcomed him

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: exceedingly.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Grettir's horse was strongly locked in an out-house. They went to sleep,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and so the night passed without Glam coming home. Then Thorhall said,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "Things have taken a good turn against thy coming, for every night Glam has

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: been wont to ride the roofs or break up the doors, even as thou canst see."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Grettir said, "Then must one of two things happen. Either he will not long

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: hold himself in, or the wonted haunting will cease for more than one night.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: I will stay here another night and see how it goes."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Then they went to Grettir's horse, and he had not been attacked. Then

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: everything seemed to the yeoman to be going one way. Now Grettir stayed for

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: another night, and the thrall did not come home. Then things seemed to the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: yeoman to be taking a very hopeful turn. He went to look after Grettir's

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: horse. When he came there, the stable was broken into, and the horse

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: dragged out to the door, and every bone in him broken asunder.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Thorhall told Grettir what had happened, and bade him save his own

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: life--"For thy death is sure if thou waitest for Glam."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Grettir answered, "The least I must have in exchange for my horse is to see

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: the thrall."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: The yeoman said that there was no good in seeing him: [Sidenote: p. 154]

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "For he is unlike any shape of man; but every hour that thou wilt stay here

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: seems good to me."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Now the day went on, and when bed-time came Grettir would not put off his

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: clothes, but lay down in the seat over against the yeoman's

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: sleeping-chamber. He had a shaggy cloak over him, and wrapped one corner of

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: it down under his feet, and twisted the other under his head and looked out

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: through the head-opening. There was a great and strong partition beam in

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: front of the seat, and he put his feet against it. The {172} doorframe was

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: all broken away from the outer door, but now boards, fastened together

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: carelessly anyhow, had been tied in front. The panelling which had been in

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: front was all broken away from the hall, both above and below the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: cross-beam; the beds were all torn out of their places, and everything was

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: very wretched[301].

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: A light burned in the hall during the night: and when a third part of the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: night was past, Grettir heard a great noise outside. Some creature had

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: mounted upon the buildings and was riding upon the hall and beating it with

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: its heels, so that it cracked in every rafter. This went on a long time.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Then the creature came down from the buildings and went to the door. When

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: the door was opened Grettir saw that the thrall had stretched in his head,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and it seemed to him monstrously great and wonderfully huge. Glam went

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: slowly and stretched himself up when he came inside the door. He towered up

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: to the roof. He turned and laid his arm upon the cross-beam and glared in

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: upon the hall. The yeoman did not let himself be heard, because the noise

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: he heard outside seemed to him enough. Grettir lay quiet and did not move.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Glam saw that a heap lay upon the seat, and he stalked in up the hall and

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: gripped the cloak wondrous fast. Grettir pressed his feet against the post

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and gave not at all. Glam pulled a second time much more violently, and the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: cloak did not move. A third time he gripped with both hands so mightily

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: that he pulled Grettir up from the seat, and now the cloak was torn asunder

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: between them.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Glam gazed at the portion which he held, and wondered much who could have

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: pulled so hard against him; and at that moment Grettir leapt under his arms

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and grasped him round {173} the middle, and bent his back as mightily as he

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: could, reckoning that Glam would sink to his knees at his attack. But the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: thrall laid such a grip on Grettir's arm that he recoiled at the might of

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: it. Then Grettir gave way from one seat to another. The beams[302] started,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and all that came in their way was broken. [Sidenote: p. 155] Glam wished

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: to get out, but Grettir set his feet against any support he could find;

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: nevertheless Glam dragged him forward out of the hall. And there they had a

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: sore wrestling, in that the thrall meant to drag him right out of the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: building; but ill as it was to have to do with Glam inside, Grettir saw

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: that it would be yet worse without, and so he struggled with all his might

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: against going out. Glam put forth all his strength, and dragged Grettir

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: towards himself when they came to the porch. And when Grettir saw that he

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: could not resist, then all at once he flung himself against the breast of

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: the thrall, as powerfully as he could, and pressed forward with both his

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: feet against a stone which stood fast in the earth at the entrance. The

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: thrall was not ready for this, he had been pulling to drag Grettir towards

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: himself; and thereupon he stumbled on his back out of doors, so that his

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: shoulders smote against the cross-piece of the door, and the roof clave

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: asunder, both wood and frozen thatch. So Glam fell backwards out of the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: house and Grettir on top of him. There was bright moonshine and broken

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: clouds without. At times they drifted in front of the moon and at times

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: away. Now at the moment when Glam fell, the clouds cleared from before the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: moon, and Glam rolled up his eyes; and Grettir himself has said that that

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: was the one sight he had seen which struck fear into him. Then such a

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: sinking came over Grettir, from his weariness and from that sight of Glam

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: rolling his eyes, that he had no strength to draw his knife and lay almost

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: between life and death.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: But in this was there more power for evil in Glam than in most other

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: apparitions, in that he spake thus: "Much eagerness hast thou shown,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Grettir," said he, "to meet with me. But no wonder will it seem if thou

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: hast no good luck from me. And this can I tell thee, that thou hast now

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: achieved one half of the power and might which was fated for thee if thou

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: hadst not met with me. Now no power have I to take that might from thee to

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: which thou hast attained. But in this may I have my way, that thou shalt

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: never become stronger than now thou art, and yet art thou strong enough, as

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: many a one shall find to his cost. Famous hast thou been till now for thy

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: deeds, but from now on shall exiles and manslaughters fall to thy lot, and

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: almost all of thy labours shall turn to ill-luck and unhappiness. Thou

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: shalt be outlawed and doomed ever to dwell alone, away from men; and then

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: lay I this fate on thee, that these eyes of mine be ever before thy sight,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and it shall seem grievous unto thee to be alone, and that shall drag thee

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: to thy death."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: And when the thrall had said this, the swoon which had [Sidenote: p. 156]

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: fallen upon Grettir passed from him. Then he drew his sword and smote off

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Glam's head, and placed it by his thigh.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Then the yeoman came out: he had clad himself whilst Glam was uttering his

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: curse, but he dare in no wise come near before Glam had fallen. Thorhall

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: praised God for it, and thanked Grettir well for having vanquished the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: unclean spirit.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Then they set to work and burned Glam to cold cinders. After, they put the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: ashes in a skin-bag and buried them as far as possible from the ways of man

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: or beast. After that they went home, and by that time it was well on to

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: day. Grettir lay down, for he was very stiff. Thorhall sent people to the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: next farm for men, and showed to them what had happened. To all those who

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: heard of it, it seemed a work of great account; and that was then spoken by

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: all, that no man in all the land was equal to Grettir Asmundarson for might

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and valour and all prowess. Thorhall sent Grettir from his house with

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: honour, and gave him a good horse and fit clothing; for all the clothes

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: which he had worn before were torn asunder. They parted great friends.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Grettir rode thence to Ridge in Water-dale, and Thorvald greeted him well,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and asked closely as to his meeting {175} with Glam. Grettir told him of

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: their dealings, and said that never had he had such a trial of strength, so

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: long a struggle had theirs been together.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Thorvald bade him keep quiet, "and then all will be well, otherwise there

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: are bound to be troubles for thee."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Grettir said that his temper had not bettered, and that he was now more

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: unruly than before, and all offences seemed worse to him. And in that he

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: found a great difference, that he had become so afraid of the dark that he

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: did not dare to go anywhere alone after night had fallen. All kinds of

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: horrors appeared to him then. And that has since passed into a proverb,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: that Glam gives eyes, or gives "glam-sight" to those to whom things seem

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: quite other than they are. Grettir rode home to Bjarg when he had done his

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: errand, and remained at home during the winter.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: (_b_) _Sandhaugar episode_ (p. 156 above)

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: There was a priest called Stein who lived at Eyjardalsá (Isledale River) in

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Barthardal. He was a good husbandman and rich in cattle. His son was

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Kjartan, a doughty man and well grown. There was a man called Thorstein the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: White who [Sidenote: p. 157] lived at Sandhaugar (Sandheaps), south of

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Isledale river; his wife was called Steinvor, and she was young and merry.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: They had children, who were young then.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: People thought the place was much haunted by reason of the visitation of

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: trolls. It happened, two winters before Grettir came North into those

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: districts, that the good-wife Steinvor at Sandhaugar went to a Christmas

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: service, according to her custom, at Isledale river, but her husband

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: remained at home. In the evening men went to bed, and during the night they

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: heard a great rummage in the hall, and by the good-man's bed. No one dared

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: to get up to look to it, because there were very few men about. The

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: good-wife came home in the morning, but her husband had vanished, and no

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: one knew what had become of him.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: The next year passed away. But the winter after, the good-wife wished again

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: to go to the church-service, and she bade her {176} manservant remain at

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: home. He was unwilling, but said she must have her own way. All went in the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: same manner as before, and the servant vanished. People thought that

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: strange. They saw some splashes of blood on the outer door, and men thought

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: that evil beings must have taken away both the good-man and the servant.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: The news of this spread wide throughout the country. Grettir heard of it;

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and because it was his fortune to get rid of hauntings and spirit-walkings,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: he took his way to Barthardal, and came to Sandhaugar on Yule eve. He

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: disguised himself[303], and said his name was Guest. The good-wife saw that

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: he was great of stature; and the farm-folk were much afraid of him. He

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: asked for quarters for the night. The good-wife said that he could have

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: meat forthwith, but "You must look after your own safety."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: He said it should be so. "I will be at home," said he, "and you can go to

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: the service if you will."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: She answered, "You are a brave man, it seems to me, if you dare to remain

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: at home."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "I do not care to have things all one way[304]," said he.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "It seems ill to me to be at home," said she, "but I cannot get over the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: river."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "I will see you over," said Guest.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Then she got ready to go to the service, and her small daughter with her.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: It was thawing, the river was in flood, and there were ice-floes in it.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Then the good-wife said, "It is impossible for man or horse to get across

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: the river."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "There must be fords in it," said Guest, "do not be afraid."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: [Sidenote: p. 158]

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "Do you carry the child first," said the good-wife, "she is the lighter."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "I do not care to make two journeys of it," said Guest, "and I will carry

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: thee on my arm."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: She crossed herself and said, "That is an impossible way; what will you do

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: with the child?"

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "I will see a way for that," said he; and then he took them both up, and

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: set the child on her mother's knee and so bore them both on his left arm.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: But he had his right hand free, and thus he waded out into the ford.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: They did not dare to cry out, so much afraid were they. The river washed at

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: once up against his breast; then it tossed a great icefloe against him, but

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: he put out the hand that was free and pushed it from him. Then it grew so

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: deep that the river dashed over his shoulder; but he waded stoutly on,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: until he came to the bank on the other side, and threw Steinvor and her

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: daughter on the land.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Then he turned back, and it was half dark when he came to Sandhaugar and

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: called for meat; and when he had eaten, he bade the farm folk go to the far

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: side of the room. Then he took boards and loose timber which he dragged

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: across the room, and made a great barrier so that none of the farm folk

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: could come over it. No one dared to say anything against him or to murmur

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: in any wise. The entrance was in the side wall of the chamber by the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: gable-end, and there was a dais there. Guest lay down there, but did not

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: take off his clothes: a light was burning in the room over against the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: door: Guest lay there far into the night.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: The good-wife came to Isledale river to the service, and men wondered how

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: she had crossed the river. She said she did not know whether it was a man

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: or a troll who had carried her over. The priest said, "It must surely be a

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: man, although there are few like him. And let us say nothing about it,"

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: said he, "it may be that he is destined to work a remedy for your evils."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: The good-wife remained there through the night.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Now it is to be told concerning Grettir that when it drew towards midnight

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: he heard great noises outside. Thereupon there came into the room a great

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: giantess. She had in one hand a trough and in the other a short-sword,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: rather a big one. She looked round when she came in, and saw where Guest

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: lay, and sprang at him; but he sprang up against her, and they struggled

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: fiercely and wrestled for a long time in the room. She was the {178}

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: stronger, but he gave way warily; and they broke all that was before them,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: as well as the panelling of the room. She dragged him forward through the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: door and so[305] into the porch, and he [Sidenote: p. 159] struggled hard

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: against her. She wished to drag him out of the house, but that did not

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: happen until they had broken all the fittings of the outer doorway and

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: forced them out on their shoulders. Then she dragged him slowly down

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: towards the river and right along to the gorge.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: By that time Guest was exceedingly weary, but yet, one or other it had to

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: be, either he had to gather his strength together, or else she would have

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: hurled him down into the gorge. All night they struggled. He thought that

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: he had never grappled with such a devil in the matter of strength. She had

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: got such a grip upon him that he could do nothing with either hand, except

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: to hold the witch by the middle; but when they came to the gorge of the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: river he swung the giantess round, and thereupon got his right hand free.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Then quickly he gripped his knife that he wore in his girdle and drew it,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and smote the shoulder of the giantess so that he cut off her right arm. So

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: he got free: but she fell into the gorge, and so into the rapids below.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Guest was then both stiff and tired, and lay long on the rocks; then he

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: went home when it began to grow light, and lay down in bed. He was all

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: swollen black and blue.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: And when the good-wife came from the service, it seemed to her that things

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: had been somewhat disarranged in her house. Then she went to Guest and

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: asked him what had happened, that all was broken and destroyed[306]. He

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: told her all that had taken place. She thought it very wonderful, and asked

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: who he was. He told her the truth, and asked her to send for the priest,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and said he wished to meet him; and so it was done.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Then when Stein the priest came to Sandhaugar, he knew soon that it was

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Grettir Asmundarson who had come there, and who had called himself Guest.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: The priest asked Grettir what he thought must have become of those men who

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: had vanished. Grettir said he thought they {179} must have vanished into

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: the gorge. The priest said that he could not believe Grettir's saying, if

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: no signs of it were to be seen. Grettir said that they would know more

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: accurately about it later. Then the priest went home. Grettir lay many days

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: in bed. The good-wife looked after him well, and so the Christmas-time

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: passed.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Grettir's account was that the giantess fell into the gulf when she got her

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: wound; but the men of Barthardal say that day came upon her whilst they

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: wrestled, and that she burst when he smote her hand off, and that she

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: stands there on the cliff yet, a rock in the likeness of a woman[307].

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: The dwellers in the dale kept Grettir in hiding there. But after Christmas

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: time, one day that winter, Grettir went to Isledale river. And when Grettir

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and the priest met, Grettir [Sidenote: p. 160] said "I see, priest, that

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: you place little belief in my words. Now will I that you go with me to the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: river and see what the likelihood seems to you to be."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: The priest did so. But when they came to the waterfall they saw that the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: sides of the gorge hung over[308]: it was a sheer cliff so great that one

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: could in nowise come up, and it was nearly ten fathoms[309] from the top to

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: the water below. They had a rope with them. Then the priest said, "It seems

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: to me quite impossible for thee to get down."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Grettir said, "Assuredly it is possible, but best for those who are men of

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: valour. I will examine what is in the waterfall, and thou shalt watch the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: rope."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: The priest said it should be as he wished, drove a peg into the cliff,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: piled stones against it, and sat by it[310].

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Now it must be told concerning Grettir that he knotted a stone into the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: rope, and so let it down to the water.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "What way," said the priest, "do you mean to go?"

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: "I will not be bound," said Grettir, "when I go into the water, so much my

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: mind forebodes me."

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: After that he got ready for his exploit, and had little on; he girded

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: himself with his short sword, and had no other weapon.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Then he plunged from the cliff down into the waterfall. The priest saw the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: soles of his feet, and knew no more what had become of him. Grettir dived

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: under the waterfall, and that was difficult because there was a great eddy,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: and he had to dive right to the bottom before he could come up behind the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: waterfall. There was a jutting rock and he climbed upon it. There was a

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: great cave behind the waterfall, and the river fell in front of it from the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: precipice. He went into the cave, and there was a big fire burning. Grettir

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: saw that there sat a giant of frightful size. He was terrible to look upon:

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: but when Grettir came to him, the giant leapt up and seized a pike, and

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: hewed at the new-comer: for with the pike he could both cut and stab. It

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: had a handle of wood: men at that time called a weapon made in such a way a

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: _heptisax_. Grettir smote against it with his short sword, and struck the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: handle so that he cut it asunder. Then the giant tried to reach back for a

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: sword which hung behind him in the cave. Thereupon Grettir smote him in the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: breast, and struck off almost all the lower part of his chest and his

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: belly, so that the entrails gushed out of him down into the river, and were

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: swept along the current.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: And as the priest sat by the rope he saw some lumps, clotted [Sidenote: p.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: 161] with blood, carried down stream. Then he became unsteady, and thought

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: that now he knew that Grettir must be dead: and he ran from keeping the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: rope and went home. It was then evening, and the priest said for certain

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: that Grettir was dead, and added that it was a great loss of such a man.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Now the tale must be told concerning Grettir. He let little space go

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: between his blows till the giant was dead. Then he {181} went further into

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: the cave; he kindled a light and examined it. It is not said how much

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: wealth he took in the cave, but men think that there was something. He

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: stayed there far into the night. He found there the bones of two men, and

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: put them into a bag. Then he left the cave and swam to the rope and shook

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: it, for he thought that the priest must be there. But when he knew that the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: priest had gone home, then he had to draw himself up, hand over hand, and

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: so he came up on to the cliff.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: Then he went home to Isledale river, and came to the church porch, with the

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: bag that the bones were in, and with a rune-staff, on which these verses

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: were exceedingly well cut:

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: There into gloomy gulf I passed,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: O'er which from the rock's throat is cast

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: The swirling rush of waters wan,

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: To meet the sword-player feared of man.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM GRETTIS SAGA
line: By giant's hall the strong stream pressed

line: D. EXTRACTS FROM BJARKA RÍMUR
(_Hrólfs saga Kraka og Bjarkarímur_ udgivne ved F. Jónsson, København,
58. Flestir [o,]muðu Hetti heldr,
hann var ekki í máli sneldr,
einn dag fóru þeir út af h[o,]ll,
svó ekki vissi hirðin [o,]ll.
59. Hjalti talar er felmtinn fær,
"f[o,]rum við ekki skógi nær,
hér er sú ylgr sem etr upp menn,
okkr drepr hún báða senn."
60. Ylgrin hljóp úr einum runn,
ógurlig með gapanda munn,
h[o,]rmuligt varð Hjalta viðr,
á honum skalf bæði leggr og liðr.
61. Ótæpt Bjarki að henni gengr,
ekki dvelr hann við það lengr,
h[o,]ggur svó að í hamri stóð,
hljóp úr henni ferligt blóð.
62. "Kjóstu Hjalti um kosti tvó,"
kappinn B[o,]ðvar talaði svó,
"drekk nú blóð eða drep eg þig hér,
dugrinn líz mér engi í þér."
63. Ansar Hjalti af ærnum móð,
"ekki þori eg að drekka blóð,
nýtir flest ef nauðigr skal,
nú er ekki á betra val."
64. Hjalti gj[o,]rir sem B[o,]ðvar biðr,
að blóði frá eg hann lagðist niðr,
drekkur síðan drykki þrjá,
duga mun honum við einn að rjá.
4. Hann hefr fengið hjartað snjalt
af h[o,]rðum móði,
fekk hann huginn og aflið alt
af ylgjar blóði.
5. Í grindur vandist grábj[o,]rn einn
í garðinn Hleiðar,
var sá margur vargrinn beinn
og víða sveiðar.
6. Bjarka er kent, að hjarðarhunda
hafi hann drepna,
ekki er hónum allvel hent
við ýta kepna.
7. Hrólfur býst og hirð hans [o,]ll
að húna stýri,
"Sá skal mestr í minni h[o,]ll
er mætir dýri."
8. Beljandi hljóp bj[o,]rninn framm
úr bóli krukku,
veifar sínum vónda hramm,
svó virðar hrukku.
9. Hjalti sér og horfir þá á,
er hafin er róma,
hafði hann ekki í h[o,]ndum þá
nema hnefana tóma.
10. Hrólfur fleygði að Hjalta þá
þeim hildar vendi,
kappinn móti krummu brá
og klótið hendi.
11. Lagði hann síðan bj[o,]rninn brátt
við bóginn hægra,
bessi fell í brúðar átt
og bar sig lægra.
12. Vann hann það til frægða fyst
og fleira síðar,
hans var lundin l[o,]ngum byst
í leiki gríðar.
13. Hér með fekk hann Hjalta nafn
hins hjartaprúða,
Bjarki var eigi betri en jafn
við býti skrúða.
23. Aðals var glaðr afreksmaðr,
austur þangað kómu,
fyrðar þeir með fránan geir
flengja þegar til rómu.
24. Ýtar býta engum frið,
unnu vel til mála,
þar fell Áli og alt hans lið
ungr í leiki stála.
25. Hestrinn beztur Hrafn er kendr,
hafa þeir tekið af Ála,
Hildisvín er hjálmrinn vendr,
hann kaus Bjarki í mála.
26. [O,]ðling bað þá eigi drafl
eiga um n[o,]kkur skipti,
það mun kosta kóngligt afl,
hann kappann gripunum svipti.
27. Ekki þótti B[o,]ðvar betr,
í burtu fóru þeir Hjalti,
létust áðr en liðinn er vetr
leita að Fróða malti.
28. Síðan ríða seggir heim
og s[o,]gðu kóngi þetta,
hann kveðst mundu handa þeim
heimta slíkt af létta.

TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM BJARKA RÍMUR

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM BJARKA RÍMUR

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM BJARKA RÍMUR
TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM BJARKA RÍMUR
line: 64. Hjalti did as Bothvar bade: he stooped down to the blood; then drank he

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM BJARKA RÍMUR
line: three sups: that will suffice him to wrestle with one man.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACTS FROM BJARKA RÍMUR

line: 4. He [Hjalti] has gained good courage and keen spirit; he got strength and
all valour from the she-wolf's blood.
5. A grey bear visited the folds at Hleithargarth; many such a ravager was
there far and wide throughout the country.
6. The blame was laid upon Bjarki, because he had slain the herdsmen's
dogs; it was not so suited for him to have to strive with men[312].
7. Rolf and all his household prepared to hunt the bear; "He who faces the
beast shall be greatest in my hall."
8. Roaring did the bear leap forth from out its den, swinging its evil
claws, so that men shrank back.
9. Hjalti saw, he turned and gazed where the battle began; nought had he
then in his hands--his empty fists alone.
10. Rolf tossed then to Hjalti his wand of war [his sword]; the warrior put
forth his hand towards it, and grasped the pommel.
11. Quickly then he smote the bear in the right shoulder; Bruin fell to the
earth, and bore himself in more lowly wise.
12. That was the beginning of his exploits: many followed later; his spirit
was ever excellent amid the play of battle.
13. Herefrom he got the name of Hjalti the stout-hearted: Bjarki was no
more than his equal.
23. Joyful was the valiant Athils when they [Bjarki and Rolf's champions]
came east to that place [Lake Wener]; troops with flashing spears rode
quickly forthwith to the battle.
24. No truce gave they to their foes: well they earned their pay; there
fell Ali and all his host, young in the game of swords.
25. The best of horses, Hrafn by name, they took from Ali; Bjarki chose for
his reward the helm Hildisvin.
26. The prince [Athils] bade them have no talk about the business; he
deprived the champions[313] of their treasures--that will be a test of his
power.
27. Ill-pleased was Bothvar: he and Hjalti departed; they declared that
before the winter was gone they would seek for the treasure [the malt of
Frothi].
28. Then they rode home and told it to the king [Rolf]; he said it was
their business to claim their due outright.

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACT FROM ÞÁTTR ORMS STÓRÓLFSSONAR

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACT FROM ÞÁTTR ORMS STÓRÓLFSSONAR

line: Now Orm went till he came to the cave. He saw the great rock, and thought

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACT FROM ÞÁTTR ORMS STÓRÓLFSSONAR
line: it was impossible for any man to move it. Then he drew on the gloves that

Poem Title: TRANSLATION OF EXTRACT FROM ÞÁTTR ORMS STÓRÓLFSSONAR
