Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: _Beowulf_, is rather the pity of it all; the legacy of mourning and

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: vengeance which is left to the survivors:

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: For never can true reconcilement grow

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Where wounds of deadly hate have struck so deep.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: It is on this note that the _Episode_ in _Beowulf_ begins: with the tragic

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: figure of Hildeburh. Hildeburh is closely related to both contending

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: parties. She is sister to Hnæf, prince of the "Half-Danes," and she is

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: wedded to Finn, king of the Frisians. Whatever may be obscure in the story,

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: it is clear that a fight has taken place between the men of Hnæf and those

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: of Finn, and that Hnæf has been slain: probably by Finn directly, though

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: perhaps by his followers[430]. A son of Finn has also fallen.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: With regard to the peoples concerned there are difficulties. Finn's

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Frisians are presumably the main Frisian race, dwelling in and around the

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: district still known as Friesland; for in the Catalogue of Kings in

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: _Widsith_ it is said that "Finn Folcwalding {249} ruled the kin of the

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Frisians[431]." Hnæf and his people are called Half-Danes, Danes and

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Scyldings; Hnæf is therefore presumably related to the Danish royal house.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: But, in no account which has come down to us of that house, are Hnæf or his

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: father Hoc ever mentioned as kings or princes of Denmark, and their

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: connection with the family of Hrothgar, the great house of Scyldings who

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: ruled Denmark from the capital of Leire, remains obscure. In _Widsith_, the

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: people ruled over by Hnæf are called "children of Hoc" (_H[=o]cingum_), and

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: are mentioned immediately after the "Sea-Danes[432]."

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Then there is a mysterious people called the _Eotens_, upon whom is placed

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: the blame of the struggle: "Verily Hildeburh had little reason to praise

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: the good faith of the Eotens." This is the typical understatement of Old

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: English rhetoric: it can only point to deliberate treachery on the part of

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: the Eotens. Our interpretation of the poem will therefore hinge largely

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: upon our interpretation of this name. There have been two views as to the

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Eotens. The one view holds them to be Hnæf's Danes, and consequently places

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: on Hnæf the responsibility for the aggression. This theory is, I think,

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: quite wrong, and has been the cause of much confusion: but it has been held

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: by scholars of great weight[433]. The other view regards the Eotens as

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: subjects {250} of Finn and foes of Hnæf. This view has been more generally

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: held, and it is, as I shall try to show, only along these lines that a

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: satisfactory solution can be found.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: The poet continues of the woes of Hildeburh. "Guiltless, she lost at the

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: war those whom she loved, child and brother. They fell as was fated,

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: wounded by the spear, and a sad lady was she. Not for naught did the

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: daughter of Hoc [i.e. Hildeburh] bewail her fate when morning came, when

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: under the sky she could behold the murderous bale of her kinsfolk...."

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Then the poet turns to the figure of Finn, king of the Frisians. His cause

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: for grief is as deep as that of Hildeburh. For he has lost that body of

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: retainers which to a Germanic chief, even as to King Arthur, was dearer

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: than a wife[434]. "War swept away all the retainers of Finn, except some

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: few."

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: What follows is obscure, but as to the general drift there is no doubt.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: After the death of their king Hnæf, the besieged Danes are led by Hengest.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Hengest must be Hnæf's retainer, for he is expressly so called (_þ[=e]odnes

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: þegn_) "the king's thegn." So able is the defence of Hengest, and so heavy

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: the loss among Finn's men, that Finn has to come to terms. Peace is made

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: between Finn and Hengest, and the terms are given fully in the _Episode_.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Unfortunately, owing to the confusion of pronouns, we soon lose our way

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: amidst the clauses of this treaty, and it becomes exceedingly difficult to

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: say who are the people who are alluded to as "they." This is peculiarly

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: unlucky because here again the critical word _Eotena_ occurs, but amid such

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: a tangle of "thems" and "theys" that it is not easy to tell from this

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: passage to which side the Eotens belong[435].

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: But one thing in the treaty is indisputable. In the midst of these

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: complicated clauses, it is said of the Danes, the retainers {251} of Hnæf,

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: that they are not to be taunted with a certain fact: or perhaps it may be

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: that they are not, when speaking amongst themselves, to remind each other

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: of a certain fact. However that may be, what _is_ clear is the _fact_, the

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: mention of which is barred. Nothing is to be said of it, even though "_they

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: were following the slayer (bana) of their lord, being without a prince,

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: since they were compelled so to do_." Here, at least, are two lines about

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: the interpretation of which we can be certain: and I shall therefore return

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: to them. We must be careful, however, to remember that the word _bana_,

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: "slayer," conveys no idea of fault or criminality. It is a quite neutral

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: word, although it has frequently been mistranslated "murderer," and has

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: thus helped to encourage the belief that Finn slew Hnæf by treachery. Of

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: course it conveys no such implication: _bana_ can be applied to one who

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: slays another in self-defence: it implies neither the one thing nor the

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: other.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Then the poet turns to the funeral of the dead champions, who are burned on

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: one pyre by the now reconciled foes. The bodies of Hnæf and of the son (or

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: sons)[436] of Hildeburh are placed together, uncle and nephew side by side,

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: whilst Hildeburh stands by lamenting.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Then, we are told, the warriors, deprived of their friends, departed to

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Friesland, to their homes and to their high-city.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Hengest still continued to dwell for the whole of that winter with Finn,

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: and could not return home because of the winter storms. But when spring

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: came and the bosom of the earth became fair, there came also the question

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: of Hengest's departure: but he thought more of vengeance than of his

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: sea-journey: "If he might bring about that hostile meeting which he kept in

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: his mind concerning the child (or children) of the Eotens." Here again the

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: word _Eotena_ is used ambiguously, but, I think, this time not without some

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: indication of its meaning. It has indeed been urged that the child or

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: children of the Eotens are Hnæf, and any other Danes who may have fallen

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: with him, and that when it is said that Hengest keeps them in mind, it is

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: meant that he is remembering his fallen comrades with a view to taking

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: {252} vengeance for them. But this would be a queer way of speaking, as

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Hengest and his living comrades would on this theory be also themselves

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: children of the Eotens[437]. We should therefore need the term to be

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: further defined: "children of the Eotens _who fell at Finnsburg_." It seems

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: far more likely, from the way in which the expression is used here, that

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: the children of the Eotens are the people _upon_ whom Hengest intends to

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: take vengeance.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Then, we are further told, Hunlafing places in the bosom of Hengest a sword

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: of which the edges were well known amongst the Eotens. Here again there has

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: been ambiguity, dispute and doubt. Hunlafing has been even bisected into a

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: chief "Hun," and a sword "Lafing" which "Hun" is supposed to have placed in

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: the bosom of Hengest (or of someone else). Upon this act of "Hun" many an

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: interpretation has been placed, and many a theory built. Fortunately it has

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: become possible, by a series of rather extraordinary discoveries, such as

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: we had little reason to hope for at this time of day, to put Hunlafing

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: together again. We now know (and this I think should be regarded as outside

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: the region of controversy) that the warrior who put the sword into

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Hengest's bosom _was_ Hunlafing. And about Hunlafing we gather, though very

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: little, yet enough to help us. He is apparently a Dane, the son of Hunlaf,

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: and Hunlaf is the brother of the two champions Guthlaf and Ordlaf[438]. Now

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Guthlaf and Ordlaf, as we know from the _Fragment_, were in the hall

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: together {253} with Hengest: it was "Guthlaf, Ordlaf and Hengest himself"

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: who undertook the defence of one of the doors against the assailants.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Guthlaf and Ordlaf were apparently sons of the king of Denmark. As

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Scyldings they would be Hnæf's kinsmen, and accompanied him to his meeting

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: with Finn. Hunlafing, then, is a nephew of two champions who were attacked

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: in the hall, and it is possible, though we cannot prove this, that his

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: father Hunlaf was himself also in the hall, and was slain in the

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: struggle[439]. At any rate, when Hunlaf's son places a sword in the bosom

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: of Hengest, this can only mean one thing. It means mischief. The placing of

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: the sword, by a prince, in the bosom of another, is a symbol of

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: war-service. It means that Hengest has accepted obligations to a Danish

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: lord, a Scylding, a kinsman of the dead Hnæf, and consequently that he

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: means to break the troth which he has sworn to Finn.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Further, we are told concerning the sword, that its edges were well known

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: amongst the Eotens. At first sight this might seem, and to many has seemed,

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: an ambiguous phrase, for a sword may be well known amongst either friends

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: or foes. The old poets loved nothing better than to dwell upon the

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: adornments of a sword, to say how a man, by reason of a fine sword which

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: had been given to him, was honoured amongst his associates at table[440].

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: But if this had been the poet's meaning here, he would surely have dwelt,

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: not upon the edges of the sword, but upon its gold-adorned hilt, or its

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: jewelled pommel. When he says the _edges_ of the sword were well known

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: amongst the Eotens, this seems to convey a hostile meaning. We know that

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: the ill-faith of the Eotens was the cause of the trouble. The phrase about

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: the sword seems therefore to mean that Hengest used this sword in order to

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: take vengeance on the Eotens, presumably for their treachery.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: The _Eotenas_, therefore, far from being the men of Hnæf and Hengest, must

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: have been their foes.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Then the poet goes on to tell how "Dire sword-bale came upon the valiant

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Finn likewise." The Danes fell upon Finn at {254} his own home, reddened

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: the floor of his hall with the life-blood of his men, slew him, plundered

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: his town, and led his wife back to her own people.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
line: Here the _Episode_ ends.

Poem Title: SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF
SECTION II. THE EPISODE IN BEOWULF

line: SECTION III. MÖLLER'S THEORY
Now our first task is to find what is the relation between the events told
in the _Fragment_ and the events told in the _Episode_ in _Beowulf_. It
can, I think, be shown that the events of the _Fragment_ precede the events
of the _Episode_ in _Beowulf_; that is to say that the fight in the hall,
of which we are told in the _Fragment_, is the same fight which has taken
place before the _Episode_ in _Beowulf_ begins, the fight which has
resulted in the slaughter over which Hildeburh laments, and which
necessitates the great funeral described in the first part of the _Episode_
How necessary it is to place the _Fragment_ here, before the beginning of
the _Episode_, will be best seen, I think, if we examine the theory which
has tried to place it elsewhere.
This is the theory, worked out elaborately and ingeniously by Möller[441],
a theory which has had considerable vogue, and many of the assumptions of
which have been widely accepted. According to Möller and his followers, the
story ran something like this:
"Finn, king of the Frisians, had carried off Hildeburh, daughter of Hoc
(1076), probably with her consent. Her father Hoc seems to have pursued
the fugitives, and to have been slain in the fight which ensued on his
overtaking them. After the lapse of some twenty years, the brothers
Hnæf and Hengest, Hoc's sons, were old enough to undertake the duty of
avenging their father's death. They make an inroad into Finn's
country."
Up to this, all is Möller's hypothesis, unsupported by any evidence, either
in the _Fragment_ or the _Episode_. It is based, so far as it has any real
foundation, upon a mythical interpretation of Finn, and upon parallels with
the Hild-story, the Gudrun-story, and a North Frisian folk-tale[442]. Some
of the {255} parallels are striking, but they are not sufficient to justify
Möller's reconstruction. The authenticity of large portions of the
folk-tale is open to doubt[443]: and these portions are vital to any
parallel with the story of _Finnsburg_; whilst we have no right to read
into the Finn story details from the Hild or Gudrun stories, unless we can
show that they are really versions of the same tale: and this cannot be
shown. Möller's suppositions as to the events before the _Episode_ in
_Beowulf_ opens, must therefore be dismissed. Möller's reconstruction then
gets into relation with the real story, as narrated in _Beowulf_:
"A battle takes place in which many warriors, among them Hnæf and a son
of Finn (1074, 1079, 1115), are killed. Peace is therefore solemnly
concluded, and the slain warriors are burnt (1068-1124).
As the year is too far advanced for Hengest to return home (ll. 1130
ff.), he and those of his men who survive remain for the winter in the
Frisian country with Finn. But Hengest's thoughts dwell constantly on
the death of his brother Hnæf, and he would gladly welcome any excuse
to break the peace which has been sworn by both parties. His
ill-concealed desire for revenge is noticed by the Frisians, who
anticipate it by themselves taking the initiative and attacking Hengest
and his men whilst they are sleeping in the hall. _This is the night
attack described in the Fragment._ It would seem that after a brave and
desperate resistance Hengest himself falls in this fight[444], but two
of his retainers, Guthlaf and Oslaf[444], succeed in cutting their way
through their enemies and in escaping to their own land. They return
with fresh troops, attack and slay Finn, and carry his queen Hildeburh
Now the difficulties of this theory will, I think, be found to be
insuperable. Let us look at some of them.
Möller's view rests upon his interpretation of the Eotens as the men of
Hnæf[446]. Since the Eotens are the aggressors, he _has_ consequently to
invent the opening, which makes Hnæf and Hengest the invaders of Finn's
country: and he _has_ therefore to relegate the _Fragment_ (in which Hnæf's
men are clearly not the attacking party but the attacked) to a later stage
in the story. But we have already seen that this interpretation of the
Eotens as the men of Hnæf is not the natural one.
Further, the assumption that Hnæf and Hengest are brothers, though still
frequently met with[447], is surely not justifiable. {256} There is nothing
which demands any such relationship, and there is much which definitely
excludes it. _After Hnæf's death_, Hengest is described as the thegn of
Hnæf: an expression without parallel or explanation, if he was really his
brother and successor. Again, we are expressly told in the _Episode_ that
the Danish retainers make terms with Finn, _the slayer of their lord, being
without a prince_. How could this be said, if Hengest was now their lord
and prince? These lines are, as we have seen, one of the few clear and
indisputable things in the poem. An interpretation which contradicts them
flatly, by making Hengest the lord of the Danish retainers, seems
self-condemned.
Again, in _Beowulf_, the poet dwells upon the blameless sorrows of
Hildeburh. We gather that she wakes up in the morning to find that the
kinsfolk whom she loves have, during the night, come to blows. "Innocent,
she lost son and brother[448]--a sad lady she." Are such expressions
natural, if Hildeburh had eloped with Finn, and her father had in
consequence been slain by him some twenty years before? If she has taken
that calmly, and continued to live happily with Finn, would her equanimity
be so seriously disturbed by the slaughter of a brother in addition?
But these difficulties are nothing compared to the further difficulties
which Möller's adherents have to face when they proceed to find a place for
the night attack as told in the _Fragment_, in the middle of the _Episode_
in _Beowulf_, i.e. between lines 1145 and 1146. In the first place we have
no right to postulate that such important events could have been passed
over in silence in the summary of the story as given in _Beowulf_. For
Möller has to assume that after the reconciliation between Hengest and
Finn, Finn broke his pledges, attacked Hengest by night, slew most of the
men who were with him, including perhaps Hengest himself; and that the
_Beowulf_-poet nevertheless omitted all reference to these events, though
they occur in the midst of the story, and are essential to an understanding
of it.
But even apart from this initial difficulty, we find that by no process of
explaining _can_ we make the night attack narrated {257} in the _Fragment_
fit in at the point where Möller places it. In the night attack the men are
called to arms by a "war-young king." This "war-young king" cannot be, as
Möller supposes, Hengest, for the simple reason that Hengest, as I have
tried to show above, far from being the brother of Hnæf, and his successor
as king, is his servant and thegn. The king can only be Hnæf. But Hnæf has
already been slain before the _Episode_ begins: and this makes it
impossible to place the _Fragment_ (in which Hnæf appears) in the middle of
the _Episode_. Further, it is said in the _Fragment_ that never did
retainers repay a lord better than did his men repay Hnæf. Now these words
would only be possible if the retainers were fighting for their lord; that
is, either defending him alive or avenging him dead. But Möller's theory
assumes that we are dealing with a period when the retainers have
definitely left the service of their lord Hnæf, after his death, and have
entered the service of his slayer, Finn. They have thus dissolved all bonds
with their former lord: they have taken Finn's money and become _his_ men.
If Finn then turns upon his new retainers and treacherously tries to slay
them, it might be said that the retainers defended their own lives stoutly:
but it would be far-fetched to say that in doing so they repaid their lord
Hnæf. Their lord, according to Möller's view, is no longer Hnæf, but Finn,
who is seeking their lives.
Against such difficulties as these it is impossible to make headway, and we
must therefore turn to some more possible view of the situation[449].
SECTION IV. BUGGE'S THEORY
Let us therefore examine the second theory, which is more particularly
associated with the name of Bugge, though it was the current theory before
his time, and has been generally accepted since.
According to this view, the _Eotenas_ are the men of Finn, and since upon
them is placed the blame for the trouble, it {258} must be Finn that makes
a treacherous attack upon his wife's brother Hnæf, who is his guest in
Finnsburg[450]. This is the fight of which the _Fragment_ gives us the
beginning. Hnæf is slain, and then follow the events as narrated in the
_Episode_: the treaty which Finn makes with Hengest, the leader of the
survivors: and the ultimate vengeance taken upon Finn by these survivors.
Here I think we are getting nearer to facts, nearer to a view which can
command general acceptance: at any rate, in so far as the fight narrated in
the _Fragment_ is placed before the beginning of the _Episode_ in
_Beowulf_. Positive evidence that this is the right place for the
_Fragment_ is scanty, yet not altogether lacking. After all, the fight in
the _Fragment_ is a night attack, and the fight which precedes the
_Episode_ in _Beowulf_, as I have tried to show, is a night attack[451].
But our reason for putting the _Fragment_ before the commencement of the
_Episode_ is mainly negative: it lies in the insuperable difficulties which
meet us when we try to place it anywhere else.
But, it will be objected, there are difficulties also in placing the
_Fragment_ before the _Episode_. Perhaps: but I do not think these
difficulties will be found to survive examination.
The first objection to supposing that the _Fragment_ narrates the same
fight as precedes the _Episode_ is, that the fight in the _Fragment_ takes
place at Finnsburg[452], whilst the fight which precedes the _Episode_
apparently takes place away from Finn's capital: for after the fighting is
over, the dead burned, and the treaty made, the warriors depart "to see
Friesland, their homes, and their high-town (_h[=e]a-burh_)[453]."
But I do not see that this involves us in any difficulty. It is surely
quite reasonable that Finnsburg--Finn's castle--where the first fight takes
place, is not, and was never meant to be, the same as Finn's capital, his
_h[=e]aburh_, his "own home." After all, when a king's name is given to a
town, the presumption is rather that the town is _not_ his capital, but
some new settlement built in a newly acquired territory. _[=E]adwinesburh_
was not the capital of King Eadwine: it was the stronghold which he held
against the Picts on the outskirts of his realm. Aosta was not the capital
of Augustus, nor Fort William of William III, nor Harounabad of Haroun al
Raschid. So here: we know that the chief town of the Frisians was not
Finnsburg, but Dorestad: "Dorostates of the Frisians[454]." The fight may
have taken place at some outlying castle built by Finn, and named after him
_Finnsburg_: then he returned, we are told, to his _h[=e]aburh_: and it is
here, _æt his sylfes h[=a]m_, "in his own home" (the poet himself seems to
emphasize a distinction) that destruction in the end comes upon him. There
is surely no difficulty here.
A second discrepancy has often been indicated. In the _Fragment_ the fight
lasts five days before any one of the defenders fall: in the _Episode_ (it
is argued) Hildeburh in the morning finds her brother slain[455]. Even were
this so, I do not know that it need trouble us much. In a detail like this,
which {260} does not go to the heart of the story, there might easily be a
discrepancy between two versions[456].
But the whole difficulty merely arises from reading more into the words of
the _Episode_ than the text will warrant. It is not asserted in the
_Episode_ that Hildeburh found her kinsfolk dead in the morning, but that
in the morning she found "murderous bale amid her kinsfolk." Hildeburh woke
up to find a fight in progress: how long it went on, the _Episode_ does not
say: but that it was prolonged we gather from ll. 1080-5: and there is no
reason why the deadly strife which Hildeburh found in the morning might not
have lasted five days or more, before it culminated in the death of Hnæf.
Thirdly, the commander in the _Fragment_ is called a "war-young king."
This, it has been said, is inapplicable to Hnæf, since he is brother of
Hildeburh, who is old enough to have a son slain in the combat.
But an uncle may be very young. Beowulf speaks of his uncle Hygelac as
young, even though he seems to imply that his own youth is partly
past[457]. And no advantage, but the reverse, is gained, even in this
point, if, following Möller's hypothesis, and assuming that the fight
narrated in the _Fragment_ takes place after the treaty with Finn, we make
the "war-young king" Hengest. For those who, with Möller, suppose Hengest
to be brother of Hnæf, will have to admit the avuncular difficulty in him
also.

line: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY

line: The cause of the struggle, according to Bugge and his adherents, is a

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: treacherous attack made by Finn upon his {261} brother-in-law Hnæf.

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: According to the _Episode_, it is the Eotens who are treacherous; so Eotens

line: must be another name for the Frisians.

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: The word occurs three times in the genitive, _Eotena_; once in the dative,

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: _Eotenum_: as a common noun it means "giant," "monster": earlier in

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: _Beowulf_ it is applied to Grendel and to the other misbegotten creatures

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: descended from Cain. But how "giant" can be applied to the Frisians, or to

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: either of the contending parties in the Finnsburg fight, remains

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: inexplicable[458]. _Eotena_ must rather be the name of some tribe. But what

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: tribe? The only people of whom we know, possessing a name at all like this,

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: are the people who colonized Kent, whom Bede calls Jutes, but whose name

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: would in Anglian be in the genitive _[=E]otna_, but in the dative

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: _[=E]otum_, or perhaps occasionally _[=E]otnum_, _[=E]otenum_[459]. Now a

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: scribe transliterating a poem from an Anglian dialect into West-Saxon

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: should, of course, have altered these forms into the corresponding

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: West-Saxon forms _[=Y]tena_ and _[=Y]tum_. But nothing would have been more

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: likely than that he would have misunderstood the tribal name as a common

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: noun, and retained the Anglian forms (altering _eotum_ or _eotnum_ into

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: _eotenum_) supposing the word to mean "giants." After all, the common noun

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: _eotenum_, "giants," was quite as like the tribal name _[=E]otum_, which

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: the scribe presumably had before him, as was the correct West-Saxon form of

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: that name, _[=Y]tum_.

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: It is difficult therefore to avoid the conclusion that the "Eotens" are

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: Jutes: and this is confirmed by three other pieces of evidence, not

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: convincing in themselves, but helpful as subsidiary arguments[460].

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: (1) We should gather from _Widsith_ that the Jutes were concerned in the

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: _Finnsburg_ business. For in that poem generally (though not always) tribes

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: connected in story are grouped together; and the Jutes and Frisians are so

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: coupled:

line: [=Y]tum [weold] Gefwulf

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY

SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: (2) There is another passage in _Beowulf_ in which _Eotenas_ is possibly

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: used in the sense of "Jutes."

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: We have seen above[461] that according to a Scandinavian tradition Lotherus

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: was exiled _in Jutiam_: and Heremod, who has been held to be the

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: counterpart of Lotherus

line: _mid Eotenum_ wearð

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: on f[=e]onda geweald forð forl[=a]cen.

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: But the identification of Lotherus and Heremod is too hypothetical to carry

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: the weight of much argument.

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: (3) Finn comes into many Old English pedigrees, which have doubtless

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: borrowed from one another. But the earliest in which we find him, and the

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: only one in which we find his father Folcwald, is that of the Jutish kings

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: of Kent[462]. Here, too, the name Hengest meets us.

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: The view that the name "Eoten" in the _Finnsburg_ story is a form of the

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: word "Jute" is, then, one which is very difficult to reject. It is one

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: which has in the past been held by many scholars and is, I think, held by

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: all who have recently expressed any opinion on the subject[463]. But this

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: renders very difficult the assumption of Bugge and his followers that the

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: word "Eoten" is synonymous with "Frisian[464]." For Frisians were not

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: Jutes. {263} The tribes were closely related; but the two words were not

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: synonymous. The very lines in _Widsith_, which couple Jutes and Frisians

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: together, as if they were related in story, show that the names were

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: regarded as those of distinct tribes. And this evidence from _Widsith_ is

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: very important, because the compiler of that list of names clearly knew the

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: story of Finn and Hnæf.

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: But this is not the only difficulty in Bugge's interpretation of the Eotens

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: as Frisians. The outbreak of war, we are told, is due to the treachery of

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: the Eotens. This Bugge and his followers interpret as meaning that Finn

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: must have treacherously attacked Hnæf. Yet the poet speaks of "the warriors

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: of Finn when the sudden danger fell upon them": _þ[=a] h[=i][=e] se f[=æ]r

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: begeat_. It is essential to _f[=æ]r_ that it signifies a sudden and

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: unexpected attack[465]: and the unexpected attack must have come, not upon

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: the assailants but upon the assailed.

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: Yet this difficulty, though it has been emphasized by Möller[466] and other

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: opponents of Bugge's view, is not insuperable[467], and I hope to show

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: below that there is no real difficulty. But it leads us to a problem not so

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: easily surmounted. If Finn made a treacherous attack upon Hnæf, and slew

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: him, how did it come that Hengest, and Hnæf's other men, made terms with

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: their murderous host?

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: In the primitive heathen days it had been a rule that the retainer must not

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: survive his vanquished lord[468]. The ferocity of this rule was

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: subsequently softened, and, in point of fact, we _do_ often hear, after

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: some great leader has been slain, of his followers accepting quarter from a

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: chivalrous foe, without being {264} therefore regarded as having acted

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: disgracefully[469]. But, if Finn had invited Hnæf and Hnæf's retainers to

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: be his guests, and had fallen upon them by treachery, the action of the

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: retainers in coming to terms with Finn, in entering his service, and

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: stipulating how much of his pay they shall receive, would be contrary to

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: all standards of conduct as understood in the Heroic Age, and would deprive

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: Hnæf's men of any sympathy the audience might feel for them. But Hnæf's men

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: are not censured: they are in fact treated most sympathetically in the

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: _Episode_, and in the _Fragment_, at an earlier point in the story, they

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: are enthusiastically applauded[470].

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: It is strange enough in any case that Hnæf's retainers should make terms

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: with the slayer of their lord. But it is not merely strange, it is

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: absolutely unintelligible, if we are to suppose that Finn has not merely

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: slain Hnæf, but has lured him into his power, and then slain him while a

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: guest.

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: It is to the credit of Bugge that he felt this difficulty: but his attempt

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: to explain it is hardly satisfactory. He fell back upon a parallel between

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: the story of the death of Rolf Kraki and the story of _Finnsburg_. We have

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: already seen that the resemblance is very close between the _Bjarkamál_,

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: which narrates the death of Rolf, and the opening of the _Finnsburg

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: Fragment_. The parallel which Bugge invoked comes from the sequel to the

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: Rolf story[471] which tells how Hiarwarus, the murderer of Rolf Kraki,

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: astonished by the devotion of Rolf's retainers, lamented their death, and

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: said how gladly he would have given quarter to such men, and taken them

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: into his service. Thereupon Wiggo, the one survivor, who had previously

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: vowed to avenge his lord, and had concealed himself with that object, came

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: forward and offered to accept these terms. Accordingly he placed his hand

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: upon the hilt of his new master's drawn sword, as if about to swear fealty

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: to him: but instead of swearing, he ran him through.

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: "Glorious and ever memorable hero, who valiantly kept his vow," says

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: Saxo[472]. Whether or no we share the exultation of {265} that excellent if

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: somewhat bloodthirsty ecclesiastic, we must admit that Wiggo's methods were

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: sensible and practical. If, singlehanded, he was to keep his vow, and

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: avenge his lord, he could only hope to do it by some such stratagem.

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: Bugge tries to explain Hengest's action on similar lines: "He does not

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: hesitate to enter the service of Finn in order thereby to carry out his

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: revenge[473]."

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: But the circumstances are entirely different. Wiggo was left alone, the

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: only survivor of Rolf's household, to face a whole army. But Hengest is no

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: single survivor: he and his fellows have made so good a defence that Finn

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: cannot overcome them by conflict on the _meðel-stede_. Not only so, but, if

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: we accept the interpretation that almost every critic and editor has put

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: upon the passage (ll. 1184-5), Hengest's position is even stronger. Finn

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: has lost almost all his thegns; the usual interpretation puts him at the

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: mercy of Hengest: at best it is a draw[474]. If, then, Hengest wants

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: vengeance upon Finn, why does he not pursue it? Instead of which, according

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: to Bugge, he enters Finn's service in order that he may get an opportunity

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: for revenge.

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: And note, that Wiggo did not swear the oath of fealty to the murderer of

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: his master Rolf: he merely put himself in the posture to do so, and then,

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: instead, ran the tyrant through forthwith. But Hengest _does_ swear the

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: oath, and _does not_ forthwith slay the tyrant. He spends the winter with

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: him, receives a sword from Hunlafing, after which his name does not occur

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: again. Finn is ultimately slain, but the names which are found in that

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: connection are those of Guthlaf and Oslaf [Ordlaf].

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: So Bugge's explanation comes to this: Hengest is fighting with success

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: against Finn, but he refrains from vengeance: instead, he treacherously

Poem Title: SECTION V. SOME DIFFICULTIES IN BUGGE'S THEORY
line: enters his service in order that he may take an opportunity of vengeance,

line: It is one of the merits of Bugge's view--one of the proofs of its general

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: soundness--that it admits of successive improvements at the hands of

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: Ayres evolves unity out of what had been before "a rapid-fire of events

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: that hit all around a central tragic situation and do not once touch it."

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: Hengest does not, Ayres thinks, enter the service of Finn with any such

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: well-formed plan of revenge as Bugge had attributed to him. Hengest was in

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: a difficult situation. It is his mental conflict, "torn between his oath to

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: Finn and his duty to the dead Hnæf," which gives unity to all that follows.

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: It is a tragedy of Hengest, hesitating, like Shakespeare's Hamlet, over the

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: duty of revenge. Prof. Ayres' statement here is too good to summarize; it

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: must be quoted at length:

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: "How did he feel during that long, blood-stained winter? He naturally

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: thought about home (_eard gemunde_, 1129), but there was no question of

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: sailing then, no need yet of decision while the storm roared outside.

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: By and by spring came round, as it has a way of doing. How did he feel

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: then? Then, like any other Northerner, he wanted to put to sea:

line: fundode wrecca,

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: gist of geardum.

SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: That is what he would naturally do. He would speak to Finn and be off;

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: in the spring his business was on the sea. That is all right as to

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS

line: All this says clearly that Hengest was thinking things over, whether he

line: Sw[=a] h[=e] ne-forwyrnde     worold-r[=æ]denne,

SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: he did not _thus_ prove recreant to his duty. But we have not been told

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: the steps by which Hengest arrived at his decision. That seems {267} to

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: be what we should naturally want to know at this point, and that is

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS

line: "Hengest's almost blunted purpose was not whetted by Hunlafing alone.

line: The effect of all this on Hengest is cumulative. Where he was before in

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: perfect balance, he is now wrought to action by the words of his

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: followers; he can control himself no longer; the balance is destroyed.

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: The restless spirit (Hengest's in the first instance, but it may be

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: thought of as referring to the entire attacking party, now of one mind)

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: could no longer restrain itself within the breast:

SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: ne meahte w[=æ]fre m[=o]d

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: forhabban in hreðre.

SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: Vengeance wins the day[476]."

line: By this interpretation Ayres has, as he claims, "sharpened some of the

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: features" of the current interpretation of the Finn story. For, as he says,

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: "in some respects the current version was very unsatisfactory; there seemed

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: Finn."

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: That Ayres' interpretation enhances the coherency of the story is beyond

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: dispute: that it does so at the cost of putting some strain upon the text

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: in one or two places may perhaps be urged[477]. But that in its main lines

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: it is correct seems to me certain: the story of Finnsburg is the tragedy of

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: Hengest--his hesitation and his revenge. Keeping this well in view, many of

Poem Title: SECTION VI. RECENT ELUCIDATIONS. PROF. AYRES' COMMENTS
line: the difficulties disappear.

line: SECTION VII. PROBLEMS STILL OUTSTANDING
Many of the difficulties disappear: but the two big ones remain. Firstly,
if "Eoten" means "Jute," as it is usually agreed that it does, why should
the Frisians be called Jutes, seeing that a Frisian is not a Jute?
Secondly, when Hengest and the other thegns of Hnæf enter the service of
the slayer of their lord, they are not blamed for so doing, but rather
excused, _þ[=a] him sw[=a] geþearfod wæs_. Such a situation is unusual; but
it becomes incredible if that slayer, whose service they enter, had fallen
upon and slain their lord by treachery, when his guest.
It seems to me that neither of these difficulties is really inherent in the
situation, but rather accidental, and owing to the way Bugge's theory,
right enough in its main lines, has been presented both by Bugge and his
followers. For it is not necessary to assume that Frisians _are_ called
_Eotenas_ or Jutes. All that we are justified in deducing from the text is
that Frisians and _Eotenas_ are both under the command of Finn. If we
suppose what the text demands, _and no more_, we are at one stroke relieved
of both our difficulties. Though "Jute" can hardly have been synonymous
with "Frisian," nothing is more probable, as I shall try to show[478], than
that a great Frisian king should have had a tribe of Jutes subject to him,
or should have had in his pay a band of Jutish mercenaries. Now if the
trouble was due to these "Eotens"--and we are told that it was[479]--our
second difficulty is also solved. It would be much more natural for Hengest
to come to terms with Finn, albeit the _bana_ of his lord, if Finn's
conduct had not been stained by treachery, and if the blame for the
original attack did not rest with him.
And, as I have said, there is nothing in the text which justifies us in
assuming that _Eotenas_ means "Frisians" and that therefore _Eotena
tr[=e]owe_ refers to Finn's breach of faith. It has indeed been argued that
_Eotenas_ and Frisians are synonymous, {269} because in the terms of peace,
whilst it is stipulated that Hengest and his comrades are to have equal
control with the _Eotena bearn_, it is further stipulated that Finn is to
give Hengest's men gifts equal to those which he gives to the _Fr[=e]sena
cynn_[480]. Here then _Eotena bearn_ and _Fr[=e]sena cynn_ are certainly
parallel, and are both contrasted with Hengest and his troops. But surely
this in no wise proves _Eotena bearn_ and _Fr[=e]sena cynn_ synonymous:
they may equally well be different sections of Finn's host, just as in
_Brunanburh_ the soldiers of Athelstan are spoken of first as _Westseaxe_,
and then as _Myrce_. Are we to argue that West-Saxons are Mercians? So in
the account of Hygelac's fatal expedition[481] the opponents are called
Franks, Frisians, _H[=u]gas_, _Hetware_. A reader ignorant of the story
might suppose these all synonymous terms for one tribe. But we know that
they are not: the _Hetware_ were the people immediately attacked--the
Frankish overlord hastened to the rescue, and was apparently helped by the
neighbouring Frisians, who although frequently at this date opposed to the
Franks, would naturally make common cause against the pirate from
overseas[482].
It was quite natural that the earlier students of the _Finnsburg Episode_,
thinking of the two opposing forces as two homogeneous tribes, and finding
mention of three tribal names, Danes, Eotens and Frisians, should have
assumed that the Eotens must be exactly synonymous with _either_ Danes _or_
Frisians. But it is now recognized that the conditions of the time
postulate not so much tribes as groups of tribes[483]. In the _Fragment_ we
have, on the side of the Danes, _Sigeferth_, prince of the _Secgan_. The
_Secgan_ are not necessarily Danes, because their lord is fighting on the
Danish side. Neither need the _Eotenas_ be Frisians, because they are
fighting on the Frisian side.
We cannot, then, argue that two tribes are identical, because engaged in
fighting a common foe: still less, because they are {270} mentioned with a
certain parallelism[484]. And anyway, it is impossible to find in the use
of the expression _Eotena bearn_ in l. 1088 any support for the
interpretation which makes _Eotena tr[=e]owe_ signify the treachery of Finn
himself. For, assuredly, the proviso that Hengest and his fellows are to
have half control as against the _Eotena bearn_ does not mean that they are
to have half control as against Finn himself. For the very next lines make
it clear that they are to enter Finn's service and become his retainers.
That Hengest and his men are to have equal rights with Finn's Jutish
followers (_Eotena bearn_) is reasonable enough: but they obviously have
not equal rights with Finn, their lord whom they are now to follow. _Eotena
bearn_ in l. 1088, then, does _not_ include Finn: how _can_ it then be used
as an argument that _Eotena tr[=e]owe_ must refer to _Finn's_ faith and his
breach of it?
Finn, then, is the _bana_ of Hnæf, but there is nothing in the text which
compels us to assume that he is the slayer of his guest.
The reader may regard my zeal to clear the character of Finn as excessive.
But it is always worth while to understand a good old tale. And it is only
when we withdraw our unjust aspersions upon Finn's good faith that the tale
becomes intelligible.
This, I know, has been disputed, and by the scholars whose opinion I most
respect.
The poet tells us that Finn was the _bana_ of Hnæf, so, says Ayres, "it is
hard to see how it helps matters[485]" to argue that Finn was not guilty of
treachery. And Lawrence argues in the same way:
"How is it possible to shift the blame for the attack from Finn to the
Eotenas when Finn is called the _bana_ of Hnæf? It does not matter
whether he killed him with his own hands or not; he is clearly held
responsible; the lines tell us it was regarded as disgraceful for the
{271} Danes to have to follow him, and the revenge at the end falls
heavily upon him. The insult and hurt to Danish pride would be very
little lessened by the assumption that someone else started the
quarrel; and for this assumption, too, the lines give no warrant[486]."
Let us take these objections in turn. I do not see how the fact that Finn
is called the _bana_ of Hnæf can prove _anything_ as to "the blame for the
attack." Of course the older editors may have thought so. Kemble translates
_bana_ "slaughterer," which implies brutality, and perhaps culpability.
Bosworth-Toller renders _bana_ "murderer," which certainly implies blame
for attack. But we know that these are mere mistranslations. Nothing as to
"blame for attack" is implied in the term _bana_: "_bana_ 'slayer' is a
perfectly neutral word, and must not be translated by 'murderer,' or any
word connoting criminality. A man who slays another in self-defence, or in
righteous execution of the law, is still his 'bane'[487]." Everyone admits
this to be true: and yet at the same time _bana_ is quoted to prove that
Finn is to blame; because, for want of a better word, we half-consciously
render _bana_ "murderer": and "murderer" _does_ imply blame. "Words," says
Bacon, "as a Tartar's bow, do shoot back upon the understanding of the
wisest."
Lawrence continues: "The lines tell us that it was regarded as disgraceful
for the Danes to have to follow him." But surely this is saying too much.
That the Frisians are not to taunt the Danes with following the slayer of
their lord is only one of two possible interpretations of the ll. 1101-3.
And even if we accept this interpretation, it does not follow that the
Danes are regarded as having done anything with which they can be _justly_
taunted. It is part of the settlement between Gunnar and Njal, that Njal's
sons are not to be taunted: if a man repeats the taunts he shall fall
unavenged[488]. Surely a man may be touchy about being taunted, without
being regarded as having done anything disgraceful. Indeed, in our case,
the poet implies that taunts would _not_ be just, _þ[=a] him sw[=a]
geþearfod wæs_. But, as I try to show below, no _þearf_ could have excused
the submission of retainers to a foe who had just slain their lord by
deliberate treachery.
"The revenge at the end falls heavily upon Finn." It does; as so often
happens where the feud is temporarily patched up, it breaks out again, as
in the stories of Alboin, Ingeld or Bolli. But this does not prove that the
person upon whom the revenge ultimately falls heavily had been a
guest-slayer. The possibility of even temporary reconciliation rather
implies the reverse.
"The insult and hurt to Danish pride would be very little lessened by the
assumption that someone else [than Finn] started the quarrel; and for this
assumption, too, the lines give no warrant." But they _do_: for they tell
us that it was due to the bad faith of the Eotens. Commentators may argue,
if they will, that "Eotens" means Finn. But the weight of proof lies on
them, and they have not met it, or seriously attempted to meet it.

line: Finn is surely entitled to be held innocent till he can be proved guilty.

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: bad faith of the Eotens: "Eotens" means "Jutes": "Jutes" means "Frisians":

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: "Frisians" means "Finn": therefore the trouble was due to the treachery of

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Finn.
