line: Now I agree that it is probable that _Eotenas_ means Jutes; and, as I have

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: said, there is nothing improbable in a Frisian king having had a clan of

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Jutes, or a body of Jutish mercenaries, subject to him. But that the

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Frisians as a whole should be called Jutes is, _per se_, exceedingly

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: improbable, and we have no shadow of evidence for it. Lawrence tries to

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: justify it by the authority of Siebs:

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: "Siebs, perhaps the foremost authority on Frisian conditions,

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: conjectures that ... the occupation by the Frisians of Jutish territory

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: after the conquest of Britain assisted the confusion between the two

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: names."

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: But _did_ the Frisians occupy Jutish territory? When we ask what is Siebs'

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: authority for the hypothesis that Frisians occupied Jutish territory, we

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: find it to be this: that because in _Beowulf_ "Jute" means "Frisian," some

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: such event must have taken place to account for this nomenclature[489]. So

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: it comes to this: the Frisians must have been called Jutes, because they

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: occupied {273} Jutish territory: the Frisians must have occupied Jutish

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: territory because they are called Jutes. I do not think we could have a

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: better example of what Prof. Tupper calls "philological legend."

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Siebs rejects Bede's statement, which places the Jutes in what is now

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Jutland: he believes them to have been immediately adjacent to the

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Frisians. For this belief that the Jutes were immediate neighbours of the

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Frisians there is, of course, some support, though not of a very convincing

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: kind: but the belief that the Frisians occupied the territory of these

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: adjacent Jutes rests, so far as I know, solely upon this identification of

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: the _Eotenas_-Jutes with the Frisians, which it is then in turn used to

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: prove.

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: But if by Jutes we understand (following Bede) a people dwelling north of

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: the Angles, in or near the peninsula of Jutland, then it is of course true

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: that (at a much later date) a colony of Frisians _did_ occupy territory

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: which is near Jutland, and which is sometimes included in the name

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: "Jutland." But, as I have tried to show above, this "North Frisian" colony

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: belongs to a period much later than that of the Finn-story: we have no

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: reason whatever to suppose that the Frisians of the Finn story are the

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: North Frisians of Sylt and the adjoining islands and mainland--the

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: _Frisiones qui habitabant Juthlandie_[490].

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: And when we have assumed, without evidence, that, at the period with which

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: we are dealing, Frisians had occupied Jutish territory, we are then further

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: asked to assume that, from this settlement in Jutish territory, such

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Frisians came to be called Jutes. Now this is an hypothesis _per se_

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: conceivable, but very improbable. Throughout the whole Heroic Age, for a

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: thousand years after the time of Tacitus, Germanic tribes were moving, and

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: occupying the territory of other people. During this period, how many

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: instances can we find in which a tribe took the name of the people whose

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: territory it occupied? Even where the name of the new home is adopted, the

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: old tribal name is _not_ adopted. For instance, the Bavarians occupied the

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: territory of the Celtic Boii, but they did not call themselves Boii, but

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Bai(haim)varii, "the dwellers in the land of the Boii"--a very {274}

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: different thing. In the same way the Jutes who settled in the land of the

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Cantii did not call themselves _Kente_, but _Cantware_, "dwellers in

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Cantium." Of course, where the old name of a country survives, it does

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: often _in the long run_ come to be applied to its new inhabitants; but this

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: takes many ages. It was not till a good thousand years after the English

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: had conquered the land of the Britons, that Englishmen began to speak and

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: think of themselves as "Britons." In feudal or 18th century days all the

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: subjects of the ruler of Britain, Prussia, Austria, may come to be called

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: British, Prussians, Austrians. But this is no argument for the period with

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: which we are dealing. The assumption, then, that a body of Frisians, simply

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: because they inhabited land which had once been inhabited by Jutes, should

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: have called themselves Jutes, is so contrary to all we know of tribal

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: nomenclature at this date, that one could only accept it if compelled by

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: very definite evidence to do so. And of such evidence there is no

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: scrap[491]. Neither is there a scrap of evidence for the underlying

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: hypothesis that any Frisians _were_ settled at this date in Jutish

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: territory.

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: And as if this were not hypothetical enough, a further hypothesis has then

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: to be built upon it: viz., that this name "Jutes," belonging to such of the

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Frisians as had settled in Jutish territory, somehow became applicable to

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Frisians as a whole. Now this might conceivably have happened, but only as

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: a result of certain political events. If the Jutish Frisians had become the

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: governing element in Frisia, it would be conceivable. But after all, we

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: know something about Frisian history, and I do not {275} think we are at

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: liberty to assume any such changes as would have enabled the Frisian

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: people, as a whole, to be called Jutes. How is it that we never get any

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: hint anywhere of this Jutish preponderance and Jutish ascendancy?

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: The argument that the "treachery of the Jutes" means the treachery of Finn,

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: King of the Frisians, has, then, no support at all.

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: One further argument there is, for attributing treason to Finn.

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: It has been urged that in other stories a husband entraps and betrays the

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: brother of his wife. But we are not justified in reading pieces of one

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: story into another, unless we believe the two stories to be really

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: connected. The Signy of the _V[o,]lsunga Saga_ has been quoted as a

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: parallel to Hildeburh[492]. Signy leaves the home of her father Volsung and

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: her brother Sigmund to wed King Siggeir. Siggeir invites the kin of his

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: wife to visit him, and then slays Volsung and all his sons, save Sigmund.

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: But it is the difference of the story, rather than its likeness, which is

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: striking. No hint is ever made of any possibility of reconciliation between

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Siggeir and the kin of the men he has slain. The feud admits of no

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: atonement, and is continued to the utterance. Siggeir's very wife helps her

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: brother Sigmund to his revenge.

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: How different from the attitude of Sigmund and Signy is the willingness of

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Hengest to come to terms, and the merely passive and elegiac bearing of

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Hildeburh! These things do not suggest that we ought to read a King Siggeir

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: treachery into the story of Finn.

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Again, the fact that Atli entices the brother of his wife into his power,

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: has been urged as a parallel. But surely it is rather unfair to erect this

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: into a kind of standard of conduct for the early Germanic brother-in-law,

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: and to assume as a matter of course that, because Finn is Hnæf's

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: brother-in-law, therefore he must have sought to betray him. The whole

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: atmosphere of the Finn-Hnæf story, with its attempted reconciliation, is as

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: opposed to that of the story of Atli as it is to the story of Siggeir.

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: The only epithet applied to Finn is _ferhð-freca_, "valiant in soul."

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Though _freca_ is not necessarily a good word, and is applied to the dragon

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: as well as to Beowulf, yet it denotes grim, fierce, almost reckless

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: courage. It does not suggest a traitor who invites his foes to his house,

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: and murders them by night.

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: I interpret the lines, then, as meaning that the trouble arose from the

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: Jutes, and, since the context shows that these Jutes were on Finn's side,

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: and against the Danes, we must hold them to be a body of Jutes in the

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
line: service of Finn[493].

Poem Title: SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION VIII. THE WEIGHT OF PROOF: THE EOTENS
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: But, as we have seen, it is objected that this interpretation of the

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: situation, absolving Finn from any charge of treachery or aggression, does

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: not "help matters[494]." Or, as Prof. Lawrence puts it, "the hurt to Danish

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: pride [in entering the service of Finn] would be very little lessened by

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: the assumption that someone else [than Finn] started the quarrel."

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: These objections seem to me to be contrary to the whole spirit of the old

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: heroic literature.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: I quite admit that there is a stage in primitive society when the act of

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: slaying is everything, and the circumstances, or motives, do not count. In

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: the Levitical Law, it is taken for granted that, if a man innocently causes

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: the death of another, as for instance if his axe break, and the axe-head

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: accidentally kill his comrade, then the avenger of blood will seek to slay

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: the homicide, just as much as if he had been guilty of treacherous murder.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: To meet such cases the Cities of Refuge are established, where the homicide

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: may flee till his case can be investigated; but even though found innocent,

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: the homicide may be at once slain by the avenger, should he step outside

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: the City of Refuge. And this "eye for eye" vengeance yields slowly: it took

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: long to establish legally in our own country the distinction between murder

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: and homicide.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: For "The thought of man" it was held "shall not be tried: as the devil

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: himself knoweth not the thought of man." Nevertheless, even the Germanic

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: _wer-gild_ system permits consideration of circumstances: it often happens

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: that no _wer-gild_ is to be paid because the slain man has been unjust, or

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: the aggressor[495], or no _wer-gild_ will be accepted because the slaying

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: was under circumstances making settlement impossible.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Doubtless in Germanic barbarism there was once a stage similar to that

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: which must have preceded the establishment of the Cities of Refuge in

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Israel[496]; but that stage had passed before the period with which we are

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: dealing; in the Heroic Age the motive _did_ count for a very great deal.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Not but what there were still the literal people who insisted upon "an eye

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: for an eye," without looking at circumstances; and these people often had

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: their way; but their view is seldom the one taken by the characters with

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: whom the poet or the saga-man sympathises. These generally hold a more

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: moderate creed. One may almost say that the leading motive in heroic

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: literature is precisely this difference of opinion between the people who

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: hold that under any circumstances it is shameful to come to an agreement

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: with the _bana_ of one's lord or friend or kinsman, and the people who are

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: willing _under certain circumstances_ to come to such an agreement.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: It happens not infrequently that after some battle in which a great chief

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: has been killed, his retainers are offered quarter, and accept it; but I do

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: not remember any instance of their doing this if, instead of an open

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: battle, it is a case of a treacherous attack. The two most famous downfalls

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: of Northern princes afford typical examples: after the battle of Svold,

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Kolbjorn Stallari accepts quarter from Eric, the chivalrous _bani_ of his

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: lord Olaf[497]; but Rolf's men refuse quarter after the treacherous murder

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: of their lord by Hiarwarus[498].

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: That men, after a fair fight, could take quarter from, or give it to, those

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: who had slain their lord or closest kinsman, is shown by abundant

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: references in the sagas and histories. For instance, when Eric, after the

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: fight with the Jomsvikings, offers quarter to his prisoners, that quarter

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: is accepted, even though their leaders, their nearest kin, and their

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: friends have been slain. The first to receive quarter is young Sigurd,

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: whose father Bui has just been killed: yet the writer obviously does not

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: the less sympathize with Sigurd, or with the other Jomsviking survivors,

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: and feels the action to be generous on the part of Eric, and in no wise

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: base on the part of the Jomsvikings[499]. But this is natural, because the

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Jomsvikings have just been defeated by Eric in fair fight. It would be

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: impossible, if Eric were represented as a traitor, slaying the Jomsvikings

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: by a treacherous attack, whilst they were his guests. Is it to be supposed

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: that Sigurd, under such circumstances, would have taken quarter from the

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: slayer of Bui his father?

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: In the _Laxdæla Saga_, Olaf the Peacock, in exacting vengeance for the

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: slaying of his son Kjartan, shows no leniency towards the sons of Osvif, on

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: whom the moral responsibility rests. But he accepts compensation in money

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: from Bolli, who had been drawn into the feud against his will. Yet Bolli

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: was the actual slayer of Kjartan, and he had taken the responsibility as

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: such[500]. And Olaf is not held to have lowered himself by accepting a

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: money payment as atonement from the slayer of his son--on the contrary "he

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: was considered to have grown in reputation" from having thus spared Bolli.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: But after Olaf's death, the feud bursts out again, and revenge in the end

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: falls heavily upon Bolli[501], as it does upon Finn.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: On this question a fairly uniform standard of feeling will be found from

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: the sixth century to the thirteenth. That it _does_ make all the difference

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: in composing a feud, whether the slaying from which the feud arises was

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: treacherous or not, can be abundantly proved from many documents, from Paul

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: the Deacon, and possibly earlier, to the Icelandic Sagas. Such composition

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: of feuds may or may not be lasting; it may or may {279} not expose to taunt

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: those who make it; but the questions which arise are precisely these: Who

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: started the quarrel? Was the slaying fair or treacherous? Upon the answer

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: depends the possibility of atonement. There may be some insult and hurt to

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: a man's pride in accepting atonement, even in cases where the other side

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: has much to say for itself. But if the slaying has been fair, composition

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: is felt to be possible, though not without danger of the feud breaking out

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: afresh.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Prof. Lawrence has suggested that perhaps, in the original version of the

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: _Finnsburg_ story, the Danes were reduced to greater straits than is

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: represented to be the case in the extant _Beowulf Episode_. He thinks that

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: it is "almost incomprehensible" that Hengest should make terms with Finn,

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: if he had really reduced Finn and his thegns to such a degree of

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: helplessness as the words of the _Episode_ state. It seems to me that the

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: matter depends much more upon the treachery or the honesty of Finn. If Finn

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: was guilty of treachery and slaughter of his guests, then it _is_

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: "unintelligible" that Hengest should spare him: but if Finn was really a

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: respectable character, then the fact that Hengest was making headway

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: against him is rather a reason why Hengest should be moderate, than

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: otherwise. To quote the _Laxdæla Saga_ again: though Olaf the Peacock lets

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: off Bolli, the _bani_ of his son Kjartan, with a money payment, he makes it

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: clear that he is master of the situation, before he shows this mercy.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Paradoxical as it sounds, it was often easier for a man to show moderation

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: in pursuing a blood feud, just _because_ he was in a strong position. It is

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: so again in the _Saga of Thorstein the White_. But the adversary must be

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: one who deserves to be treated with moderation.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Of course it is quite possible that Prof. Lawrence is right, and that in

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: some earlier and more correct version the Danes may have been represented

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: as so outnumbered by the Frisians that they had no choice except to

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: surrender to Finn, and enter his service, or else to be destroyed. But,

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: whether this be so or no, all parallel incidents in the old literature show

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: that their choice between these evil alternatives will depend upon whether

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Finn, the _bana_ of their lord, slew that lord by deliberate and

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: premeditated treachery whilst he was his guest, or whether he {280} was

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: embroiled with him through the fault of others, under circumstances which

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: were perfectly honourable. If the latter is the case, then Hnæf's men

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: _might_ accept quarter. Their position is comparable with that of Illugi at

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: the end of the _Grettis Saga_[502]. Illugi is a prisoner in the hands of

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: the slayers of Grettir and he charges them with having overcome Grettir,

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: when already on the point of death from a mortifying wound, which they had

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: inflicted on him by sorcery and enchantment. The slayers propose to Illugi

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: terms parallel to those made to the retainers of Hnæf. "I will give thee

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: thy life," says their leader, "if thou wilt swear to us an oath not to take

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: vengeance on any of those who have been in this business."

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Now, note the answer of Illugi: "That might have seemed to me a matter to

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: be discussed, if Grettir had been able to defend himself, and if ye had

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: overcome him with valour and courage; but now it is not to be looked for

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: that I will save my life by being such a coward as art thou. In a word, no

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: man shall be more harmful to thee than I, if I live, _for never can I

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: forget how it was that ye have vanquished Grettir_. Much rather, then, do I

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: choose to die."

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Now of course it would have been an "insult and hurt" to the pride of

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Illugi, or of any other decent eleventh century Icelander, to have been

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: compelled to swear an oath not to avenge his brother, even though that

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: brother had been slain in the most chivalrous way possible; and it would

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: doubtless have been a hard matter, even in such a case, for Illugi to have

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: kept his oath, had he sworn it. But the treachery of the opponents puts an

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: oath out of the question, just as it must have done in the case of the

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: followers of King Cynewulf[503] or of Rolf Kraki, and as it must have done

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: in the case of the followers of Hnæf, had the slaying of Hnæf been a

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: premeditated act of treachery on the part of Finn.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: In the _Njáls Saga_, Flosi has to take up the feud for the slain Hauskuld.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Flosi is a moderate and reasonable man, so the first thing he does is to

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: enquire into the _circumstances_ under which Hauskuld was slain. Flosi

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: finds that the circumstances, and the outrageous conduct of the slayers,

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: give him no choice {281} but to prosecute the feud. So in the end he burns

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Njal's hall, and in it the child of Kari.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Now to have burned a man's child to death might well seem a deed impossible

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: of atonement. Yet in the end Flosi and Kari are reconciled by a full

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: atonement, _the father of the slain child actually taking the first

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: step_[504]. And all this is possible because Flosi and Kari recognise that

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: each has been trying to play his part with justice and fairness, and that

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: each is dragged into the feud through the fault of others. When Flosi has

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: said of his enemy, "I would that I were altogether such a man as Kari is,"

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: we feel that reconciliation is in sight.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Very similar is the reconciliation between Alboin and Thurisind in

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Longobard story, but with this difference, that here it is Alboin who seeks

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: reconciliation by going to the hall of the man whose son he has slain, thus

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: reversing the parts of Flosi and Kari; and reconciliation is possible--just

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: barely possible.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Again, when Bothvar comes to the hall of Rolf, and slays one of Rolf's

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: retainers, the other retainers naturally claim full vengeance. Rolf insists

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: upon investigating the _circumstances_. When he learns that it was his own

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: man who gave the provocation, he comes to terms with the slayer.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Of course it was a difficult matter, and one involving a sacrifice of their

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: pride, for the retainers of Hnæf to come to any composition with the _bana_

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: of their lord; but it is not unthinkable, if the quarrel was started by

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Finn's subordinates without his consent, and if Finn himself fought fair.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: But had the slaying been an act of premeditated treachery on the part of

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Finn, the atonement would, I submit, have been not only difficult but

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: impossible. If the retainers of Hnæf had had such success as our poem

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: implies, then their action under such circumstances is, as Lawrence says,

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: "almost incomprehensible." If they did it under compulsion, and fear of

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: death, then their action would be contrary to all the ties of Germanic

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: honour, and would entirely deprive them of any sympathy the audience might

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: otherwise have felt for them. Yet it is quite obvious that the retainers of

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Hnæf are precisely the people with whom the audience is expected to

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: sympathise[505].

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: In any case, the feud was likely enough to break out again as it did in the

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: case of Alboin and Thurisind, and equally in that of Hrothgar and Ingeld.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Indeed, the different versions of the story of the feud between the house

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: of Hrothgar and the house of Froda are very much to the point.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Much the oldest version--probably in its main lines quite historical--is

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: the story as given in _Beowulf_. Froda has been slain by the Danes in

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: pitched battle. Subsequently Hrothgar, upon whom, as King of the Danes, the

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: responsibility for meeting the feud has devolved, tries to stave it off by

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: wedding his daughter Freawaru to Ingeld, son of Froda. The sympathy of the

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: poet is obviously with the luckless pair, Ingeld and Freawaru, involved as

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: they are in ancient hatreds which are not of their making. For it is

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: foreseen how some old warrior, who cannot forget his loyalty to his former

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: king, will stir up the feud afresh.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: But Saxo Grammaticus tells the story differently. Froda (Frotho) is

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: treacherously invited to a banquet, and then slain. By this treachery the

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: whole atmosphere of the story is changed. Ingeld (Ingellus) marries the

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: daughter of his father's slayer, and, for this, the old version reproduced

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: by Saxo showers upon him literally scores of phrases of scorn and contempt.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: The whole interest of the story now centres not in the recreant Ingeld or

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: his wife of treacherous race, but in the old warrior Starkad, whose spirit

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: and eloquence is such that he can bring Ingeld to a sense of his "vast

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: sin[506]," can burst the bonds of his iniquity, and at last compel him to

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: take vengeance for his father.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: In the _Saga of Rolf Kraki_ the story of Froda is still further changed. It

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: is a tale not only of treachery but also of slaying of kin. Consequently

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: the idea of any kind of atonement, however temporary, has become

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: impossible; there is no hint of it.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Now the whole atmosphere of the Hengest-story in _Beowulf_ is parallel to

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: that of the _Beowulf_ version of the Ingeld-story: agreement is possible,

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: though it does not prove to be permanent. There is room for much hesitation

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: in the minds of Hengest and of Ingeld: they remain the heroes of the story.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: But if Finn had, as is usually supposed, invited Hnæf to his fort and then

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: {283} deliberately slain him by treachery, the whole atmosphere would have

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: been different. Hengest could not then be the hero, but the foil: the

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: example of a man whose spirit fails at the crisis, who does the utterly

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: disgraceful thing, and enters the service of his lord's treacherous foe.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: The hero of the story would be some other character--possibly the young

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Hunlafing, who, loyal in spite of the treachery and cowardice of his leader

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: Hengest, yet, remaining steadfast of soul, is able in the end to infuse his

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: own courage into the heart of the recreant Hengest, and to inspire all the

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: perjured Danish thegns to their final and triumphant revenge on Finn.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
line: But that is not how the story is presented.

Poem Title: SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION IX. ETHICS OF THE BLOOD FEUD
SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: The theory, then, which seems to fit in best with what we know of the

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: historic conditions at the time when the story arose, and which fits in

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: best with such details of the story as we have, is this:

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Finn, King of Frisia, has a stronghold, Finnsburg, outside the limits of

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Frisia proper. There several clans and chieftains are assembled[507]: Hnæf,

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Finn's brother-in-law, prince of the Hocings, the Eotens, and Sigeferth,

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: prince of the Secgan; whether Sigeferth has his retinue with him or no is

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: not clear.

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: But the treachery of the Eotens causes trouble: they have some old feud

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: with Hnæf and his Danes, and attack them by surprise in their hall. There

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: is no proof that Finn has any share in this treason. It is therefore quite

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: natural that in the _Episode_--although the treachery of the Eotens is

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: censured--Finn is never blamed; and that in the _Fragment_, Finn has

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: apparently no share in the attack on the hall, at any rate during those

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: first five days to which the account in the _Fragment_ is limited.

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: The attack is led by Garulf (_Fragment_, l. 20), presumably the prince of

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: the Eotens: and some friend or kinsman is urging Garulf not to hazard so

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: precious a life in the first attack. And {284} here, too, the situation now

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: becomes clearer: if Garulf is the chief of the attacking people, we can

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: understand one of his kinsmen or friends expostulating thus: but if he is

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: merely one of a number of subordinates despatched by Finn to attack the

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: hall, the position would not be so easily understood.

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Garulf, however, does not heed the warning, and falls, "first of all the

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: dwellers in that land." The _Fragment_ breaks off, but the fight goes on:

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: we can imagine that matters must have proceeded much as in the great attack

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: upon the hall in the _Nibelungen lied_[508]. One man after another would be

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: drawn in, by the duty of revenge, and Finn's own men would wake to find a

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: battle in progress. "The sudden bale (_f[=æ]r_) came upon them." Finn's son

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: joins in the attack, perhaps in order to avenge some young comrade in arms;

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: and is slain, possibly by Hnæf. Then Finn _has_ to intervene, and Hnæf in

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: turn is slain, possibly, though not certainly, by Finn himself. But

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Hengest, the thegn of Hnæf, puts up so stout a defence, that Finn is unable

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: to take a full vengeance upon all the Danes. He offers them terms. What are

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Hengest and the thegns to do?

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Finn has slain their lord. But they are Finn's guests, and they have slain

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Finn's son in his own house. Finn himself is, I take it, blameless. _It is

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: here that the tragic tension comes in._ We can understand how, even if

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Hengest had Finn in his power, he might well have stayed his hand. So peace

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: is made, and all is to be forgotten: solemn oaths are sworn. And Finn keeps

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: his promise honestly. He resumes his position of host, making no

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: distinction between Eotens, Frisians and Danes, who are all, for the time

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: at least, his followers.

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: I think we have here a rational explanation of the action of Hengest and

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: the other thegns of Hnæf, in following the slayer of their lord.

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: The situation resembles that which takes place when Alboin seeks

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: hospitality in the hall of the man whose son he has slain, or when Ingeld

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: is reconciled to Hrothgar. Very similar, too, {285} is the temporary

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: reconciliation often brought about in an Icelandic feud by the feeling that

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: the other side has something to say for itself, and that both have suffered

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: grievously. The death of Finn's son is a set off against the death of

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Hnæf[509]. But, as in the case of Alboin and of Ingeld, or of many an

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Icelandic Saga, the passion for revenge is too deep to be laid to rest

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: permanently. This is what makes the figure of Hengest tragic, like the

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: figure of Ingeld: both have plighted their word, but neither can keep it.

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: The assembly breaks up. Finn and his men go back to Friesland, and Hengest

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: accompanies them: of the other Danish survivors nothing is said for the

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: moment: whatever longings they may have had for revenge, the poet

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: concentrates all for the moment in the figure of Hengest.

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Hengest spends the winter with Finn, but he cannot quiet his conscience:

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: and in the end, he accepts the gift of a sword from a young Danish prince

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Hunlafing, who is planning revenge. The uncles of Hunlafing, Guthlaf and

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Oslaf [Ordlaf], had been in the hall when it was attacked, and had

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: survived. It is possible that the young prince's father, Hunlaf, was slain

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: then, and that his son is therefore recognised as having the nominal

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: leadership in the operations of vengeance[510]. Hengest, by accepting the

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: sword, promises his services in the work of revenge, and makes a great

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: slaughter of the treacherous Eotens. Perhaps he so far respects his oath

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: that he leaves the simultaneous attack upon Finn to Guthlaf and Oslaf

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: [Ordlaf]. Here we should have an explanation of _swylce_: "in like

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: wise[511]"; and also an explanation of the omission of Hengest's name from

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: the final act, the slaying of Finn himself. Hengest made the Eotens {286}

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: feel the sharpness of his sword: and in like wise Guthlaf and Oslaf

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: conducted their part of the campaign. Of course this is only a guess: but

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: it is very much in the manner of the Heroic Age to get out of a difficulty

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: by respecting the letter of an oath whilst breaking its spirit--just as

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Hogni and Gunnar arrange that the actual slaying of Sigurd shall be done by

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
line: Guttorm, who had not personally sworn the oath, as they had.

Poem Title: SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
SECTION X. AN ATTEMPT AT RECONSTRUCTION
SECTION XI. GEFWULF, PRINCE OF THE JUTES
line: SECTION XI. GEFWULF, PRINCE OF THE JUTES

Poem Title: SECTION XI. GEFWULF, PRINCE OF THE JUTES
SECTION XI. GEFWULF, PRINCE OF THE JUTES
line: Conclusive external evidence in favour of the view just put forward we can

Poem Title: SECTION XI. GEFWULF, PRINCE OF THE JUTES
line: hardly hope for: for this reason, amongst others, that the names of the

Poem Title: SECTION XI. GEFWULF, PRINCE OF THE JUTES
line: actors in the Finn tragedy are corrupted and obscured in the different

line: SECTION XII. CONCLUSION
But, apart from any such confirmation, I think that the theory offers an
explanation of the known facts of the case, and that it is the only theory
yet put forward which does. It enables us to solve many minor difficulties
that hardly otherwise admit of solution. But, above all, it gives a tragic
interest to the story by making the actions of the two main characters,
Finn and Hengest, intelligible and human: they are both great chiefs,
placed by circumstances in a cruel position. Finn is no longer a
treacherous host, plotting the murder of his guests, without even having
the courage personally to superintend the dirty work: and Hengest is not
guilty of the shameful act of entering the service of a king who had slain
his lord by treachery when a guest. The tale of _Finnsburg_ becomes one of
tragic misfortune besetting great heroes--a tale of the same type as the
stories of Thurisind or Ingeld, of Sigurd or Theodric.
FRISIA IN THE HEROIC AGE
It is now generally recognised that loose confederacies of tribes were, at
the period with which we are dealing, very common. Lawrence says this
expressly: "The actors in this drama are members of two North Sea tribes,
or _rather groups of tribes_[513]"; and again[514]: "At the time when the
present poem was put into shape, we surely have to assume for the Danes and
Frisians, not compact and unified political units, but groups of tribes
held somewhat loosely together, and sometimes known by tribal names."
This seems to me a quite accurate view of the political situation in the
later Heroic Age. The independent tribes, as they existed at the time of
Tacitus, tended to coalesce, and from such coalition the nations of modern
Europe are gradually evolved. In the seventh and eighth centuries a great
king of Northumbria or Frisia is likely to be king, not of one only, but of
many allied tribes. I cannot therefore quite understand why some scholars
reject so immediately the idea that the Eotens are not necessarily
Frisians, but rather a tribe in alliance with the Frisians. For if, as they
admit, we are dealing not with two compact units, but with two groups of
tribes, why must we assume, as earlier scholars have done, that _Eotenas_
must be synonymous either with Frisians or Danes? That assumption is based
upon the belief that we _are_ dealing with two compact units. It has no
other foundation. I can quite understand Kemble and Ettmüller jumping at
the conclusion that the Eotens _must_ be identical with the one side or the
other. But once we have recognised that confederacies of tribes, rather
than individual tribes, are to be expected in the period with which we are
dealing, then surely no such assumption should be made.
I think we shall be helped if we try to get some clear idea of the
nationalities concerned in the struggle. For to judge by the analogy of
other contemporary Germanic stories, there probably is some historic basis
for the _Finnsburg_ story: and even if the fight is purely fictitious, and
if Finn Folcwalding never existed, still the Old English poets would
represent the fictitious Frisian king in the light of what they knew of
contemporary kings.
Now the Frisians were no insignificant tribe. They were a power,
controlling the coasts of what was then called the "Frisian Sea[515]."
Commerce was in Frisian hands. Archaeological evidence points to a lively
trade between the Frisian districts and the coast of Norway[516]. From
about the sixth century, when "Dorostates of the Frisians" is mentioned by
the Geographer of Ravenna (or the source from which he drew) in a manner
which shows it to have been known even in Italy as a place of peculiar
{289} importance[517], to the ninth century, when it was destroyed by
repeated attacks of the Vikings, the Frisian port of Dorestad[518] was one
of the greatest trade centres of Northern Europe[519]. By the year 700 the
Frisian power had suffered severely from the constant blows dealt to it by
the Frankish Mayors of the Palace. Yet evidence seems to show that even at
that date the Frisian king ruled all the coast which intervened between the
borders of the Franks on the one side and of the Danes on the other[520].
When a zealous missionary demonstrated the powerlessness of the heathen
gods by baptizing three converts in the sacred spring of Fosetisland, he
was carried before the King of Frisia for judgement[521].
At a later date the "Danes" became the controlling power in the North Sea;
but in the centuries before the Viking raids began, the Frisians appear to
have had it all their own way.
Finn, son of Folcwald, found his way into some English genealogies[522]
just as the Roman Emperor did into others. This also seems to point to the
Frisian power having made an impression on the nations around.
We should expect all this to be reflected in the story of the great Frisian
king. How then would a seventh or eighth century Englishman regard Finn and
his father Folcwalda? Probably as paramount chiefs, holding authority over
the tribes of the South and East coast of the North Sea, similar to that
which, for example, a Northumbrian king held over the tribes settled along
the British coast. Indeed, the whole story of the Northumbrian kings, as
given in Bede, deserves comparison: the relation with the subordinate
tribes, the alliances, the feuds, the attempted assassinations, the loyalty
of the thegns--this is the atmosphere amid which the Finn story grew up in
England, and if we want to understand the story we must begin by getting
this point of view.
But, if this be a correct estimate of tribal conditions at the time the
_Finnsburg_ story took form, we no longer need far-fetched explanations to
account for Finnsburg not being in Friesland. It is natural that it should
not be, just as natural as that the contemporary Eadwinesburg should be
outside the ancient limits of Deira. Nor do we need any far-fetched
explanations why the Frisians should be called _Eotenas_. That the King of
Frisia should have had Jutes under his rule is likely enough. And this is
all that the words of the _Episode_ demand.
PART IV
APPENDIX

line: But surely many objections have to be met. Firstly, as Dr Bradley admits,

Poem Title: A. A POSTSCRIPT ON MYTHOLOGY IN _BEOWULF_
line: of this section have undergone alteration in order to bring them into

Poem Title: A. A POSTSCRIPT ON MYTHOLOGY IN _BEOWULF_
line: connection with the prefixed matter." And why should we assume that the

Poem Title: A. A POSTSCRIPT ON MYTHOLOGY IN _BEOWULF_
line: "passus" of _Beowulf_ correspond to pieces of {295} parchment of various

Poem Title: A. A POSTSCRIPT ON MYTHOLOGY IN _BEOWULF_
line: sizes of which an earlier exemplar consisted? These "passus" vary in length

Poem Title: A. A POSTSCRIPT ON MYTHOLOGY IN _BEOWULF_
line: from 43 lines to 142, a disproportion by no means extraordinary for the

Poem Title: A. A POSTSCRIPT ON MYTHOLOGY IN _BEOWULF_
line: sections of one and the same poem, but very awkward for the pages of one

Poem Title: A. A POSTSCRIPT ON MYTHOLOGY IN _BEOWULF_
line: and the same book, however roughly constructed. One of the "passus" is just

Poem Title: A. A POSTSCRIPT ON MYTHOLOGY IN _BEOWULF_

Poem Title: A. A POSTSCRIPT ON MYTHOLOGY IN _BEOWULF_

line: to pause: 16 at the beginning or end of a speech: 18 others at a point

line: where the narrative is resumed after some digression or general remark.

line: Only eight remain, and even with these, there is generally some pause in

Poem Title: A. A POSTSCRIPT ON MYTHOLOGY IN _BEOWULF_
line: the narrative at the point indicated. In only two instances does a "passus"
